Swimming pools, spas, and similar structures above ground, on ground, or in ground, shall be maintained in a safe, clean, sanitary, secure, and structurally and mechanically sound condition, so as to prevent stagnant water, which is conducive to the harboring or breeding of mosquitoes or other insects. A finding by a code enforcement officer, planning director, sworn police officer, or a health official of the county environmental health department shall constitute prima facie evidence that stagnant water in a swimming pool is conducive to the breeding or harboring of mosquitoes or other insects. All swimming pools shall be completely surrounded by a fence or other barrier having a minimum height of four feet. When the sides of an above ground pool are used as the barrier, the ladder or steps shall be capable of being secured, locked or removed to prevent access; or the ladder or steps shall be surrounded by a barrier which meets these requirements. Citations for violations of this section shall be returned to the municipal court and shall subject the offender to fine not to exceed one thousand dollars per offense and/or order of the court to correct or repair the violation. (Ord. No. 16-004, 7-7-16)

div.head: Chapter 8.20 - WEED AND LITTER CONTROL
div.p:
Section:
8.20.010 - Title. This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the "Auburn anti-litter and weed control ordinance." (Ord. 129 § 1, 1990) 8.20.020 - Purpose and intent. The ordinance codified in this chapter is adopted pursuant to authority contained in the Charter of the city, and the need to protect and preserve the public health, safety, morality, order, property value and welfare of the citizens of the city, as well as to maintain a healthful, clean and beautiful environment. This chapter is intended to supplement and to coordinate existing litter control and removal efforts. (Ord. 129 § 2, 1990) 8.20.030 - Definitions. As used in this chapter: "Commercial handbill" means any printed or written matter, any sample or device, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, paper, booklet, or any other printed or otherwise reproduced original or copies of any matter of literature, which: 1. Advertises for sale any merchandise, product, commodity, service or thing; 2. Directs attention to any business, mercantile or commercial establishment, or other activity, for the purpose of either directly or indirectly promoting the interest thereof by sales; 3. Directs attention to or advertises any meeting, theatrical or other performance, exhibition, or event of any kind, for which an admission fee is charged; 4. Which, while containing reading or pictorial matter other than advertising matter, is predominately and essentially an advertisement, and is distributed or circulated for advertising purposes, or for the private benefit and gain of any person so engaged as advertiser or distributor. "Construction sites" means and includes any private or public property upon which repairs to existing buildings, construction of new buildings or demolition of existing structures is taking place. "Elements" means and includes any element whether created by nature or created by man, which with reasonable foreseeability could carry litter from one place to another. Elements shall include, but not be limited to, air current, rain, water current and animals. "Handbill" means and includes any written or printed matter, any sample or device, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, paper, booklet, or any other printed matter or literature which is not delivered by United States mail, except that handbills shall not include a newspaper. "Litter" means and includes any uncontainerized manmade or man-used waste which, if deposited within the city otherwise than in a litter receptacle, tends to create a danger to public health, safety and welfare or to impair the environment of the people of the city. Litter may include, but is not limited to, any garbage, trash, refuse, confetti, debris, grass clippings, or other lawn or garden waste, newspaper, magazine, glass, metal, plastic or paper container or other construction material, motor vehicle parts, furniture, oil, carcass of a dead animal, or nauseous or offensive matter of any kind, or any object likely to injure any person or create a traffic hazard. "Litter receptacle" means and includes any container which is designed to receive litter and to prevent the escape of litter deposited therein, which is of such size or sufficient capacity to hold all litter generated between collections. "Park" means and includes a public or private park, reservation, playground, recreation center, or any public or private area devoted to active or passive recreation, or any other area under the supervision of any state, county or local park authority. "Parking lot" means and includes any private or public property with provisions for parking vehicles, to which the public is invited or to which the public is permitted to use or which is visible from any public place or private premises. "Private premises" means and includes any dwelling house, building or other structure designed to be used, either wholly or in part, for private residential purposes, whether inhabited or temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant, and shall include any yard, ground, walk, driveway, porch, steps, vestibule, mailbox, or other structure belonging or appurtenant to such dwelling house or other structure. "Public place" means and includes any and all streets, boulevards, avenues, lanes, alleys or other public ways, and parks, squares, plazas, grounds and buildings frequented by the general public, whether publicly or privately owned. (Ord. 129 § 3, 1990) 8.20.040 - Litter in public places. No person shall throw, drop or in any way deposit litter on any public property except in authorized and identified litter receptacles. (Ord. 129 § 4, 1990) 8.20.050 - Conveyance of loose materials on public ways. A. It is unlawful for any person to transport in any vehicle or by any other means or manner, any loose material or articles likely to sift, fall, spill or be blown about on any public street, alley or other public way in the city. B. It is unlawful for any person to overload such vehicles. Each operator of such a vehicle shall cover the contents or shall convey the contents entirely secured in covered boxes or other containers. In case any of the contents of any such vehicle shall become blown, scattered or spilled upon any public street, alley or other public way or place in the city, the person in charge thereof shall immediately clean up, gather up or cause to be gathered up any such spilled, blown or scattered materials. (Ord. 129 § 5, 1990) 8.20.060 - Maintenance of property. A. Every owner or occupant or lessee of a house or building used for residence, business or commercial purpose shall maintain litter collection and storage areas in a clean condition and ensure that all litter is properly containerized. Failure to so maintain clean litter collection and storage areas shall constitute a violation of this section. B. All litter that is subject to movement by the elements shall be secured by the owner of the premises where it is found before the same is allowed to be removed by the elements to adjoining premises. C. It shall be the duty of any person owning or controlling a house or other building or premises, including vacant lots visible from any public place or private premises, to maintain such premises in a reasonably clean and orderly manner and to a standard conforming to other orderly premises in that vicinity. It shall be a violation of this section to abandon, neglect or disregard the condition or appearance of any premises so as to permit it to accumulate any litter thereon. D. The owner or person in control of any public place, including but not limited to restaurants, shopping centers, fast food outlets, stores, hotels, motels, industrial establishments, office buildings, apartment buildings, housing projects, gas stations, and hospitals and clinics shall at all times keep the premises clean of all litter and shall take measures including daily cleanup of the premises to prevent litter from being carried by the elements to adjoining premises. It shall be a violation of this section to abandon, neglect or disregard the appearance or condition of such premises so as to permit it to accumulate litter thereon. E. The person owning, operating or in control of a loading or unloading dock shall at all times maintain the dock area free of litter in such a manner that litter will be prevented from being carried by the elements to adjoining premises. F. The property owners and the prime contractors in charge of any construction site shall maintain the construction site in such a manner that litter will be prevented from being carried by the elements to adjoining premises. All litter from construction activities and any related activities shall be picked up at the end of each work day and placed in containers which will prevent litter from being carried by the elements to adjoining premises. G. Persons owning, occupying or in control of any premises shall keep the sidewalks and alleys adjacent thereto free from litter. In residential areas, owners or occupants shall sweep or rinse off the sidewalks abutting their premises as often as may be required to keep the walk and street reasonably free from dirt, paper and waste. H. It is unlawful for any person who is in control of any premises upon which is located or on whose behalf there is maintained any container or refuse, waste or garbage which has been containerized in accordance with a contract for its removal to allow that refuse, waste or garbage to remain uncollected beyond the day provided by the contract for its collection and removal, or in any case to allow that container to remain unemptied for longer than fourteen days or in any case until after the refuse, waste or garbage creates any condition which is offensive to persons upon any private premises or public place. (Ord. 129 § 6, 1990) 8.20.070 - Litter receptacles. A. Every owner, occupant, tenant or lessee using or occupying any public place shall provide adequate litter receptacles of sizes, numbers and types as required to contain all litter generated by those persons frequenting that public place. B. Any parking lot shall be equipped with litter receptacles in compliance with this section. C. The owner or person in control of private premises shall maintain litter receptacles for collection of litter as necessary and in such a manner that litter will be prevented from being carried by the elements to adjoining premises. D. All litter shall be removed periodically from litter receptacles as is necessary to maintain their usefulness. E. Persons placing litter in litter receptacles shall do so in such a manner as to prevent litter from being carried from the receptacles by the elements. F. No person shall cause the removal, upsetting, mutilation, defacing or tampering with litter receptacles or cause the contents thereof to be spilled or to be strewn in or upon any public place or private premises. G. Litter receptacles shall not be placed in any location where they may obstruct vehicular traffic or unreasonably obstruct pedestrian traffic. H. Litter receptacles located on publicly owned properties shall be conspicuously identified and shall be free of commercial advertising. (Ord. 129 § 7, 1990) 8.20.080 - Dumping. A. No person shall dump or otherwise dispose of litter or other refuse or unsightly matter on any public or private property unless such property specifically is approved by the city and/or the state of Georgia for dumping. It is a violation of this chapter to dump any household or nonhousehold refuse into any private dumpster or private collection system without permission from the owner. B. In reference to any discarded furniture, appliances, machinery or other oversized litter or trash, arrangements must be made by the property owner at his/her/its expense for removal and disposal. Under no circumstances while awaiting removal shall a discarded refrigerator, icebox, freezer, washer, dryer, or stove or other item capable of entrapping a child be left in an area accessible to children. Any such items left outside for a period of seven days or more, unless part of an authorized business operation, will be presumed to be discarded and, after reasonable notice, removed by the city, at the property owner's expense. (Ord. 129 § 8, 1990) 8.20.090 - Litter from vehicles. It is unlawful to throw, drop or otherwise deposit or dispose of litter or any other refuse from any moving vehicle upon any public or private streets located within the city. (Ord. 129 § 9, 1990) 8.20.100 - Scavenging. No person other than the owner thereof, or any agent or any employee of the city, shall interfere with any container placed for the purpose of storing refuse pending collection, or remove or take any of the contents thereof, or remove any such container from the location where the same shall have been placed by the owner thereof. (Ord. 129 § 10, 1990) 8.20.110 - Handbills. A. No person shall throw, scatter or cast any kind of handbill in or upon any public place within the city; and no person shall hand out or distribute or sell any commercial handbill in any public place; provided, however, it shall not be unlawful for any person to hand out or distribute handbills or any other thing which is otherwise permitted or authorized by law in any public place to any person willing to accept such handbill or other thing, without payment therefor. B. No person shall deposit, fasten, throw, scatter or cast any handbill in or upon any vehicle. The provisions of this section shall not be deemed to prohibit the handing of any noncommercial handbill to the owner or occupant of any vehicle who is willing to accept it without payment therefor. C. No person shall place any handbill in or upon any private premises which are vacant, unless attached in such a manner as not to deface the property. D. No person shall place any handbill upon any premises if requested by anyone thereon not to do so or if there is placed on the premises in a conspicuous position near any entrance thereof a sign bearing notice indicating in any manner that the occupants of the premises do not desire to have any such handbills left upon such premises. E. No person shall place any handbill in or upon any private premises which are inhabited, except by handing or transmitting any such handbill directly to any other person than present in or upon the private premises. However, in case of inhabited private premises which are not posted against handbill distribution as provided in this chapter, any person, unless requested by someone upon such premises not to do so, may place or deposit any handbill in or upon the inhabited private premises, if the handbill is placed or deposited so as to prevent it from being carried by the elements about such premises or elsewhere, except that mailboxes may not be so used when prohibited by federal postal laws or regulations. F. Any person distributing handbills shall maintain the area which they are utilizing free of any litter caused by or related to the handbill distribution. G. The provisions of this chapter shall not be construed to prohibit the distribution of newspapers and political pamphlets. (Ord. 129 § 11, 1990) 8.20.120 - Public utility poles. No person shall post or affix any notice, poster or other paper or device calculated to attract the attention of the public to any public utility pole or other public lamppost or structure unless expressly authorized by law. (Ord. 129 § 12, 1990) 8.20.130 - Growth limitations. A. It is unlawful for any person, corporation or other entity owning, claiming or occupying or having supervision or control with any real property, occupied or unoccupied within the city, to permit weeds, grass, brush, or any objectionable or unsightly matter to grow to a greater height than that of twelve inches upon such real property within one hundred fifty feet of any property line which abuts street, right-of-way, alleys, utility easements, subdivided additions, developed property or any buildings or other structures. B. It shall be the duty of any person, corporation or other entity owning, claiming, occupying or having supervision or control of any real property occupied or unoccupied, within the city, to keep the area adjacent to his property line, including portions of his property between the property line or sidewalk and the curb and portions of his property between the property line and any alley pavement or other roadway, or if there is no curb, then within ten feet outside such property line, free and clear of the matter referred to in subsection A above. All vegetation not regularly cultivated and which exceeds twelve inches in height shall be presumed to be objectionable and unsightly, except that regularly cultivated crops shall not be allowed to grow within the right-of-way of any public street or easement, but shall be kept mowed. It is unlawful for any person to fail to cut and remove the matter referred to in subsection A from the areas described herein, and such failure shall constitute a violation hereof upon the terms and conditions of this section. C. It shall be the duty of any person, corporation or other entity owning, claiming, occupying or having supervision or control of any real property, to cut and remove all such weeds, grass, brush, and other objectionable or unsightly matter as often as may be necessary, provided that the removing and cutting of same at least once in every thirty days shall be deemed a compliance with this section and to use every precaution to prevent the same growing on such premises as to become a nuisance. (Ord. 129 § 13, 1990) 8.20.140 - Notice to correct violation. In the event that any person, corporation, partnership or other entity, claiming, occupying or having supervision or control of any real property occupied or unoccupied within the city, fails to comply with the provisions of this chapter, it shall be the duty of the entity charged with enforcement of this chapter to give ten days' notice in writing to such person, corporation, partnership or other entity violating the terms of this chapter by letter addressed to such person, corporation, partnership or other entity. Such letter shall be sent certified mail, return receipt requested to the last known address of the entity in violation. Such notice shall state the alleged violation of this chapter and the remedial measures needed to be taken for such entity to cease to be in violation of this chapter. (Ord. 129 § 14, 1990) 8.20.150 - Abatement by city. If any person, corporation, partnership of other entity fails or refuses to comply with the provisions of Section 8.20.140 within ten days after receipt of notice from city that the property is in violation, the city, through its agents and employees, may go upon such property and do or cause to be done the work necessary to obtain compliance with this chapter. (Ord. 129 § 15, 1990) 8.20.160 - Recovery by city of expenses. The expenses incurred in correcting the condition of such property, and any administrative costs involved, shall be paid by the city and charged to the owner of such property. A bill for such services shall be promptly sent to the owner of the property on which such services were performed. Should the amount go unpaid for a period of thirty days following the mailing of the bill, the city may institute a lawsuit and seek recovery of the amounts expended by the city including applicable interest and attorney's fees. This provision is not exclusive of any other rights or remedies available to the city under its Charter and under the laws of the state. (Ord. 129 § 16, 1990) 8.20.170 - Violations—Penalty—Enforcement. A. Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter, shall be subject to a fine, upon conviction in the municipal court of the city, and each and every day that the premises shall remain in a condition in violation of the terms of this chapter shall constitute a separate offense. This section shall be in addition to and cumulative of the provisions of the abatement of the nuisance and the charge of the cost of same against the owner of the premises by the city as set out in Section 8.20.150. The fine imposed under this chapter shall not exceed one thousand dollars per offense. B. Citations under this chapter shall be issued by the police department ordering those cited to appear before the municipal court of the city at a designated date and time. C. It shall be the responsibility of the police department to enforce this chapter. (Ord. 129 § 17, 1990)

div.head: Chapter 8.24 - EMERGENCY POWERS
Chapter 8.28 - SMOKING REGULATIONS
div.p:
Sections:
8.28.010 - Definitions. The following words and phrases, whenever used in this chapter, shall be construed as defined in this section: "Bar area" means an area as defined by the owner or manager which is primarily devoted to the serving of alcoholic beverages for consumption by guests on the premises and in which the serving of food is only incidental to the consumption of such beverages. The term "bar area" shall not include a restaurant dining area. Designated Smoking Area. 1. "Designated smoking area" in a restaurant means an area of contiguous seating where smoking is permitted and which (a) is situated so existing barriers and existing ventilation systems are used to minimize the toxic effects of smoke; (b) is marked by appropriate signs; and (c) does not include service lines or cashier areas. 2. "Designated smoking area" in a place of employment means a separate enclosed room where smoking is permitted and which (a) is not frequented by the public or non-smoking employees; (b) is not a work area, restroom or meeting room; and (c) is not the only employee lounge or cafeteria. "Dining area" means an interior area containing a counter or tables upon which food is served. "Place of employment" means any enclosed area under the control of a public or private employer which employees frequent during the course of employment including, but not limited to, work areas, restrooms, employee lounges, cafeterias and snack bars, conference and meeting rooms, lobbies and reception areas. 1. A private residence is not a "place of employment" unless it is used as a child care facility or a health care facility. 2. The dining area of a restaurant shall not be treated as a "place of employment" under this chapter. "Private enclosed offices" means any enclosed area within a place of employment. Private enclosed offices must have walls that extend from floor to ceiling and a closable door. "Public place" means any enclosed area to which the public is invited or in which the public is permitted including, but not limited to, restaurants, stores, waiting rooms, lobbies, restrooms, enclosed shopping malls, educational, recreational and health care facilities, child care facilities, auditoriums, theaters, arenas and meeting rooms. A private residence is not a "public place" unless it is used as a child care facility or a health care facility. "Restaurant" means any establishment or area which is primarily devoted to the serving of food to the public or guests and which contains a dining area. The term "restaurant" shall not include a cocktail lounge or tavern if said cocktail lounge or tavern is a "bar area" as previously defined. The term "restaurant" shall not include any dining area located within a health care, educational, or child care facility. Food courts within enclosed shopping malls shall be treated as restaurants under this chapter. "Retail tobacco store" means a retail store in which the sale of tobacco products designed for smoking comprises more than fifty percent of its receipts. "Smoking" means inhaling, exhaling, burning or carrying any lighted cigar, cigarette, pipe or other smoking equipment in any manner or form. (Ord. 167 § 1, 1994) 8.28.020 - Regulation of smoking. Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, smoking is prohibited in all public areas and places of employment within the city of Auburn, Georgia. (Ord. 167 § 2, 1994) 8.28.030 - Exceptions. The regulation of smoking pursuant to this chapter shall not apply in the following areas: A. Bar areas; B. Hotel and motel rooms rented to guests, except for those rooms designated by such hotels and motels as no smoking rooms; C. Retail tobacco stores; D. Retail stores of five thousand square feet or less in which tobacco products are sold over the counter; provided, however, this exception does not include the non-restaurant areas of such retail stores that sell prescription medicines; E. Restaurants with a seating capacity of fifty or less; F. Designated smoking areas in restaurants with a seating capacity in excess of fifty; provided, that such designated smoking area shall not comprise more than fifty percent of such restaurant's seating capacity; G. Designated smoking area in a place of employment, except that no designated smoking area shall be permitted in any health care or child care facility; H. Private enclosed offices in places of employment of three thousand square feet or less which management declares to be designated smoking areas except that smoking shall not be permitted in the presence of nonsmokers; I. Places of employment occupied exclusively by smokers and which is not subject to public access in the ordinary course of business; J. Banquet or meeting rooms when these rooms are being used for private functions. (Ord. 167 § 3, 1994) 8.28.040 - Posting of signs. "No smoking" signs shall be conspicuously posted in any public place or places of employment where smoking is prohibited. Such signs shall contain letters of not less than two inches in height or the international symbol for "no smoking" consisting of a pictorial representation of a burning cigarette enclosed in a red circle, with a red bar bisecting the circle. (Ord. 167 § 4, 1994) 8.28.050 - Enforcement. A. Enforcement of this chapter shall be the responsibility of the city of Auburn police department, which may initiate any action to seek enforcement of this chapter either on its own motion or upon information provided by any citizen. B. Any owner, operator or manager of any establishment, regulated by this chapter shall inform persons violating this chapter of the appropriate provisions. In the event persons violating this chapter refuse to cease smoking after being informed by such owner, operator or manager, the person smoking, not the owner, operator or manager, shall be subject to an action for violation of the chapter. (Ord. 167 § 5, 1994) 8.28.060 - Other applicable laws. This chapter shall not be interpreted or construed to permit smoking where it is otherwise restricted or prohibited by other applicable laws, regulations or policies. (Ord. 167 § 6, 1994) 8.28.070 - Violation—Penalty. Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined not less than ten dollars nor more than five hundred dollars for each offense. (Ord. 167 § 7, 1994)

div.head: Chapter 8.34 - ON-SITE SEWAGE MANAGEMENT
div.p:
Sections:
8.34.010 - Adoption. The city adopts by reference the Rules of the State of Georgia Department of Human Resources for On-Site Sewage Management Systems, Chapter 290-5-26, and incorporates it into this chapter by reference as though fully set forth verbatim. (Ord. 274, 2001) 8.34.020 - Enforcement. The mayor and council of the city designates and empowers the Barrow County Health Department and all authorized employees thereof as the persons with the authority to enforce the provisions of this chapter within the city limits. (Ord. 274, 2001) 8.34.030 - Penalties. Citations for violations of this chapter within the city limits shall be returned to the city municipal court for disposition. Such violations shall be punishable by fines not to exceed one thousand dollars and/or thirty days in jail. (Ord. 274, 2001) Title 9 - PUBLIC PEACE, MORALS AND WELFARE Chapters:

div.head: Chapter 9.04 - OFFENSES BY OR AGAINST PUBLIC OFFICERS AND GOVERNMENT
div.p:
Sections:
9.04.010 - Profanity or disorderliness in the presence of town officials. It is unlawful for any person or persons to use any profanity or be disorderly in any manner when in presence of the city clerk, assistant clerk or before any city official while they are in their official capacity and discharging their assigned duties. (Ord. 4, 1963)

div.head: Chapter 9.08 - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC DECENCY
div.p:
Sections:
9.08.010 - Spitting. It is unlawful for any person to spit upon the sidewalks, or upon the floors of places of worship, buses, public halls, theaters or other public places. (Ord. 63A § 3-12, 1977) 9.08.020 - Drunkenness. It is unlawful for any person to be and appear on the streets of the city, or in any public place or place of business patronized by the public in an intoxicated condition. Upon finding of guilt for the violation of this section, the offender shall be subject to imprisonment for a term not exceeding six months or by fine not exceeding one hundred dollars, either of the penalties to be in the discretion of the judge of municipal court. (Ord. 63A § 3-13, 1977) 9.08.030 - Violating quarantine regulations. It is unlawful for any person or persons to violate any of the quarantine regulations established by the council of the city, and upon conviction such violator shall be punished as prescribed by ordinance. (Ord. 37, 1963) 9.08.040 - Maintaining a disorderly house. A. A person who keeps, maintains or owns, either by himself or others, a common, ill-governed and disorderly house, to the encouragement of gaming, drinking, misuse of any controlled substance (as described by state law), or other misbehavior, or to the common disturbance of the neighborhood or orderly citizens, is in violation of this section. B. Any person in violation of this section, and upon conviction, plea of guilty, or plea of nolo contendere, shall be punished according to provisions of the city's charter. 1. A fine of not less than one hundred ten dollars nor more than one thousand dollars, which fine shall not, except as provided in subdivision 3 of this subsection, be subject to suspension, stay or probation. 2. A period of confinement of not more than ten days, and/or sentence of not more than thirty days of community service work, which period may be suspended, stayed or probated. 3. If the payment of the fine required under subdivision 1 of this subsection will impose an economic hardship on the defendant, at the discretion of the chief of police, or the clerk of court, the fine may be probated. (Ord. 107 §§ 1, 2, 1989) 9.08.050 - Bring your own bottle "brown bagging" prohibited. A. It is unlawful for any person to bring his or her own alcoholic beverage (brown bag), as that term is defined in OCGA § 3-1-2, into any establishment which is licensed under any of the business license provisions of the city of Auburn, Georgia, whether or not such establishment is licensed or unlicensed to sell and/or serve alcoholic beverages. B. It is unlawful for any corporation, partnership, individual or other entity who maintains a business which is lawfully licensed by the city of Auburn, Georgia, to permit, allow or suffer the consumption or possession of any alcoholic beverages, as that term is defined in OCGA § 3-1-2, within any premises licensed for business under the laws and ordinances of the city of Auburn, Georgia. Subsection B of this section shall not apply to nor shall it affect the lawful sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption, if permitted, by licensees operating under a valid license issued under the terms of this section providing for consumption of alcoholic beverages on the premises. (Ord. 179, 1993)

div.head: Chapter 9.12 - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC PEACE
Chapter 9.16 - OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY
div.p:
Sections:
9.16.010 - Destruction of property. A. It is unlawful for any person to wilfully damage, destroy, mar or deface any property of the city, or of another. B. It is unlawful for any unauthorized person to tamper with, to open, or to paint any equipment of the departments and bureaus of the city, including fire hydrants and water mains. (Ord. 63A § 1-1, 1977) 9.16.020 - Defacing buildings. It is unlawful for any person to write, paint or draw upon, to carve any letter, word or design upon; or to mutilate or deface in any way any wall, fence, public building, private dwelling, place or institution of learning, place of worship, statue or monument, now or hereafter erected in the city. (Ord. 63A § 1-2, 1977) 9.16.030 - Disturbing graves. It is unlawful to disturb any grave, or deface, pull up or remove anything placed to mark a grave, or any railing or wall placed around a grave. (Ord. 63A § 1-3, 1977) 9.16.040 - Injuring or destroying cemetery property. It is unlawful to destroy, mutilate, deface, injure or remove any tomb, monument, gravestone or other structure placed in the cemetery, or any fence, railing or other work used for the protection or ornament of any tomb, monument, gravestone or other structure, or for the ornament or protection of the cemetery, or to wilfully destroy, cut, break, remove or injure any tree, shrub or plant that may have been planted or may be growing in the cemetery, or to commit any other trespass within the limits of the cemetery. (Ord. 63A § 1-4, 1977) 9.16.050 - Damaging property of public utilities. A. Generally. It is unlawful for any person intentionally and without authority to injure or destroy any meter, pipe, conduit, wire, line, post, lamp or other apparatus belonging to a company, or the city, engaged in the manufacture or sale of electricity, gas, water, telephone or other public services, or intentionally and without authority to prevent a meter from properly registering the quantity of such service supplied, or in any way to interfere with the proper action of such company or the city, intentionally to divert any services of such company or the city or otherwise intentionally and without authority to use or cause to be used, without the consent of such company or the city, any service manufactured, sold or distributed by such company or the city. B. Presumption of Guilt. Where there is no evidence to the contrary, the person performing any of the illegal acts referred to in subsection A and/or the person, who with knowledge of such violation receives the benefit of such service without proper charge as a result of such improper action shall be presumed to be responsible for such acts of tampering or diversion. C. Penalty. Violators of the foregoing section shall be punished by a fine not to exceed one hundred dollars and costs of imprisonment in the city jail for not more than six months, or by any one or more of these punishments, subject to all limitation contained in the City Charter. (Ord. 63A § 1-5, 1977) 9.16.060 - Refusal to leave premises. It is unlawful for any person or persons to refuse to leave any public or private place when asked or ordered to do so by the owner or person or persons having jurisdiction of said place. Violation of this section shall be punishable as prescribed by ordinance. (Ord. 7, 1963)

div.head: Chapter 9.20 - WEAPONS
div.p:
Sections:
9.20.010 - Firing of cannons or artillery. It is unlawful for any person, within the corporate limits of the city, to fire a cannon, or other piece of artillery, without special permission of the mayor and city council. (Ord. 63A § 4-6, 1977) 9.20.020 - Discharge of weapons. It is unlawful for any person to shoot any firearm, air gun, pistol, or like instrument or weapon within the limits of the city, except as permitted by O.C.G.A. § 16-11-103. (Ord. No. 15-010, 11-5-15; Ord. 63A § 4-16, 1977) 9.20.030 - Arrows. It is unlawful for any person, within the corporate limits of the city, to discharge any arrow of any kind or character from a bow; provided, however, nothing herein shall be construed to prohibit the use of bows and arrows indoors, or any established archery range under the personal and direct supervision of a person at least eighteen years of age. (Ord. 63A § 4-17, 1977) 9.20.040 - Reserved. Editor's note— Ord. No. 15-010, adopted November 5, 2015, repealed § 9.20.040 which pertained to the sale of .22 caliber firearms and derived from Ord. 63A, § 4-7 adopted in 1977. 9.20.050 - Knives, pistols or similar weapons—Display in show windows visible from streets. It is unlawful for any person or corporation to expose for sale by displaying in any open show window visible from the street any pistol, revolver, automatic, derringer, metal knucks, dirk, sword-in-cane, spear, Bowie knife, switchblade knife or any blackjack or other similar weapon. Violations of this section shall be considered as an offense under this code and punishable as such. (Ord. 63A § 4-18, 1977) 9.20.060 - Reserved. Editor's note— Ord. No. 15-010, adopted November 5, 2015, repealed § 9.20.060, which pertained to the sale and delivery of certain firearms and derived from Ord. 63A, § 4-8 adopted in 1977. 9.20.070 - Knives, razors or similar weapons—Possession. A. It is unlawful for any person to have in his possession, except within his own domicile, any of the following implements unless same are securely wrapped so as not to be readily available for use: 1. Any knife which has a blade which opens automatically by hand pressure applied to a button, spring or other device in the handle, the blade of which when open projects from the handle more than two inches; 2. Any knife which has any obstruction or other device of any kind which holds the blade partly open, the blade of which when open projects from the handle more than two inches; 3. Any knife of any kind, the blade of which when open projects from the handle more than three inches. This is intended to include all knives such as butcher knives or other knives which do not close; 4. Any razor; 5. Any ice pick or similar device having a sharp point, except that this shall not apply to any person delivering ice. B. Any violation of this section or any subsection thereof shall be considered an offense and any person, firm or corporation convicted of violating the terms of this section or any subsection thereof shall be subject to the penalties provided by city ordinance. (Ord. 63A § 4-19, 1977) 9.20.080 - Destruction of confiscated weapons. A. Declared Nuisance. Any bludgeon, metal knuckles, firearms or knife, designed for the purpose of offense and defense, or any other dangerous or deadly weapon or instrument of like kind used in the commission of a misdemeanor, are declared to be nuisances per se. B. Destruction. The commissioner of public safety is authorized and directed to destroy all dangerous or deadly weapons used in the commission of a misdemeanor. Such commissioner, or his duly authorized agents, shall wait one year from date of conviction or after the exhaustion of any appeals related to the case, before destroying the weapon. (Ord. 63A § 4-9, 1977) 9.20.090 - Concealed weapons. A. It is unlawful for any person to carry any concealed firearms on their person, auto, or otherwise, without a lawful permit or being authorized to carry firearms by authority of law. B. It is unlawful for any person to carry any concealed weapons such as knucks, blackjacks, straight razors, switch blades, knives, rocks, sticks or any device that could be used for inflicting bodily harm. Any person or persons found guilty of this ordinance shall be deemed an offender and punished as prescribed by ordinance. (Ord. 6, 1963)

div.head: Chapter 9.24 - MARIJUANA
div.p:
Sections:
9.24.010 - Unlawful activities. It is unlawful for any person to possess, have under his control, manufacture, deliver, distribute, dispense, administer, purchase, sell, or possess with intent to distribute marijuana. (Ord. 194 § 1, 1994) 9.24.020 - Probation conditions. Whenever any person who has not previously been convicted of any offense under this chapter, or of any statute of the United States or of any state relating to narcotic drugs, marijuana, or stimulant, depressant or hallucinogenic drugs, pleads guilty to or is found guilty of possession of marijuana, the court may, without entering a judgment of guilt, and with the consent of such person, defer further proceedings and place him on probation upon such reasonable terms and conditions as the court may require, preferably terms which require the person to undergo a comprehensive rehabilitation program, including if necessary, medical treatment, not to exceed twelve months, designed to acquaint him with the ill effects of drug abuse and to provide him with knowledge of the gains and benefits which can be achieved by being a good member of society. Upon violation of a term or condition, the court may enter an adjudication of guilt and proceed accordingly. Upon fulfillment of the terms and conditions, the court shall discharge the person and dismiss the proceedings against him. Discharge and dismissal under this chapter shall be without court adjudication of guilt and shall not be deemed a conviction for purposes of this chapter or for purposes of disqualifications or disabilities imposed by law upon conviction of a crime. Discharge and dismissal under this chapter may occur only once with respect to any person. (Ord. 194 § 2, 1994) 9.24.030 - Violation—Penalty. Notwithstanding any law to the contrary, any person who is charged with possession of marijuana, which possession is of one ounce or less, and such person would have qualified for the conditional discharge provided for in this chapter but for the fact that the judge chose not to avail himself of the authority granted by this chapter or that the person violated the conditions imposed by the court, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and punished by imprisonment for a period not to exceed twelve months or a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars or both, or community service work not to exceed twelve months. Subsequent offenses of possession of one ounce or less of marijuana shall be punished as a misdemeanor. (Ord. 194 § 3, 1994)

div.head: Chapter 9.28 - THEFT BY SHOPLIFTING
div.p:
Sections:
9.28.010 - Definition. A person commits the offense of theft by shoplifting when he alone or in concert with another person, with the intent of appropriating merchandise to his own use without paying for the same or to deprive the owner of possession thereof or of the value thereof, in whole or in part, does any of the following: A. Conceals or takes possession of the goods or merchandise of any store or retail establishment; B. Alters the price tag or other price marking on goods or merchandise of any store or retail establishment; C. Transfers the goods or merchandise of any store or retail establishment from one container to another; D. Interchanges the label or price tag from one item of merchandise with a label or price tag for another item of merchandise; or E. Wrongfully causes the amount paid to be less than the merchant's stated price for the merchandise. (Ord. 195 § 1, 1994) 9.28.020 - Violation—Penalty. A. A person convicted of the offense of theft by shoplifting, as provided in Section 9.28.010 of this chapter when the property which was the subject of the theft is one hundred dollars or less in value, shall be punished as for a misdemeanor; provided, however, that: 1. Upon conviction of a second such offense, in addition to or in lieu of any imprisonment which might be imposed, the defendant shall be fined not less than two hundred fifty dollars and the fine shall not be suspended or probated; and 2. Upon conviction of a third such offense, in addition to or in lieu of any fine which might be imposed, the defendant shall be punished by imprisonment for not less than thirty days; and such sentence of imprisonment shall not be suspended, probated, deferred or withheld except as in the discretion of the court the sentence of incarceration may be imposed as an equivalent number of hours of community service. In addition to any imprisonment which might be imposed, the defendant shall be fined not less then five hundred dollars and the fine shall not be suspended or probated; and 3. Upon conviction of a fourth or subsequent such offense, the defendant shall be punished by imprisonment for not less than three months nor more than twelve months; and the first thirty days of such sentence shall not be suspended, probated, deferred or withheld. In addition to any imprisonment which might be imposed, the defendant shall be fined not less than one thousand dollars and the fine shall not be suspended or probated. B. A person convicted of the offense of theft by shoplifting, as provided in Section 9.28.010 of this chapter, when the property which was the subject of the theft exceeds one hundred dollars in value, commits a felony and shall be punished by imprisonment for not less than one nor more than ten years. However, the court, in its discretion may treat the offense as a misdemeanor and impose a punishment in accordance with that as outlined under subsection (A)(3) of this section. C. In all cases involving theft by shoplifting, the term "value" means the actual retail price of the property at the time and place of the offense. The unaltered price tag or other marking on property, or duly identified photographs thereof, shall be prima facie evidence of value and ownership of the property. D. This section shall in no way affect the authority of a sentencing judge to provide for a sentence to be served on weekends or during the nonworking hours of the defendant. E. Whenever any person who has not previously been convicted of any offense under this chapter, or of any statute of the United States or of any state relating to theft, pleads guilty to or is found guilty of theft by shoplifting, the court may, without entering a judgment of guilt, and with the consent of such person, defer further proceedings and place him on probation upon such reasonable terms and conditions as the court may require, preferable terms which require the person to undergo a comprehensive rehabilitation program designed to acquaint him with the ill effects of committing theft and to provide him with knowledge of the gains and benefits which can be achieved by being a good member of society. Upon violation of a term or condition, the court may enter an adjudication of guilt and proceed accordingly. Upon fulfillment of the terms and conditions, the court shall discharge the person and dismiss the proceedings against him. Discharge and dismissal under this chapter shall be without court adjudication of guilt and shall not be deemed a conviction for purposes of this chapter or for purposes of disqualifications or disabilities imposed by law upon conviction of a crime. Discharge and dismissal under this chapter may occur only once with respect to any person. F. Notwithstanding any law to the contrary, any person who is charged with shoplifting, and such person would have qualified for the conditional discharge provided for in this chapter but for the fact that the judge chose not to avail himself of the authority granted by this chapter or that the person violated the conditions imposed by the court, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and punished by imprisonment for a period not to exceed twelve months or a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars, or both, or community service work not to exceed twelve months. (Ord. 195 § 2, 1994)

div.head: Chapter 9.32 - THEFT GENERALLY
div.p:
Sections:
9.32.010 - Definitions. As used in this chapter: "Deprive" means without justification: 1. To withhold property of another permanently or temporarily; or 2. To dispose of the property so as to make it unlikely that the owner will recover it. "Financial institution" means a bank, insurance company, credit union, building and loan association, investment trust, or other organization held out to the public as a place of deposit of funds or medium of savings or collective investment. "Property of another" means and includes property in which any person other than the accused has an interest but does not include property belonging to the spouse of an accused or to them jointly. (Ord. 204 § 1, 1994) 9.32.020 - Theft by taking. A person commits the offense of theft by taking when he unlawfully takes or, being in lawful possession thereof, unlawfully appropriates any property of another with the intention of depriving him of the property, regardless of the manner in which the property is taken or appropriated. (Ord. 204 § 2, 1994) 9.32.030 - Theft by deception. A. A person commits the offense of theft by deception when he obtains property by any deceitful means or artful practice with the intention of depriving the owner of the property. B. A person deceives if he intentionally: 1. Creates or confirms another's impression of an existing fact or past event which is false and which the accused knows or believes to be false; 2. Fails to correct a false impression of an existing fact or past event which he has previously created or confirmed; 3. Prevents another from acquiring information pertinent to the disposition of the property involved; 4. Sells or otherwise transfers or encumbers property intentionally failing to disclose a substantial and valid known lien, adverse claim, or other legal impediment to the enjoyment of the property, whether such impediment is or is not a matter of official record; or 5. Promises performance of services which he does not intend to perform or knows will not be performed. Evidence of failure to perform standing alone shall not be sufficient to authorize a conviction under this subsection. C. "Deceitful means" and "artful practice" do not, however, include falsity as to matters having no pecuniary significance, or exaggeration by statements unlikely to deceive ordinary persons in the group addressed. (Ord. 204 § 3, 1994) 9.32.040 - Theft by conversion. A. A person commits the offense of theft by conversion when, having lawfully obtained funds or other property of another including, but not limited to, leased or rented personal property, under an agreement or other known legal obligation to make a specified application of such funds or a specified disposition of such property, he knowingly converts the funds or property to his own use in violation of the agreement or legal obligation. This section applies whether the application or disposition is to be made from the funds or property of another or from the accused's own funds or property in equivalent amount when the agreement contemplates that the accused may deal with the funds or property of another as his own. B. When, under subsection A of this section, an officer or employee of a government or of a financial institution fails to pay on an account, upon lawful demand, from the funds or property of another held by him, he is presumed to have intended to convert the funds or property to his own use. (Ord. 204 § 4, 1994) 9.32.050 - Theft of services. A person commits the offense of theft of services when by deception and with the intent to avoid payment he knowingly obtains services, accommodations, entertainment or the use of personal property which is available only for compensation. (Ord. 204 § 5, 1994) 9.32.060 - Theft of lost or mislaid property. A person commits the offense of theft of lost or mislaid property when he comes into control of property that he knows or learns to have been lost or mislaid and appropriates the property to his own use without first taking reasonable measures to restore the property to the owner. (Ord. 204 § 6, 1994) 9.32.070 - Theft by receiving stolen property. A. A person commits the offense of theft by receiving stolen property when he receives, disposes of, or retains stolen property which he knows or should know was stolen unless the property is received, disposed of or retained with intent to restore it to the owner. "Receiving" means acquiring possession or control or lending on the security of the property. B. In any prosecution under this section it shall not be necessary to show a conviction of the principal thief. (Ord. 204 § 7, 1994) 9.32.080 - Theft by receiving property stolen in another state. A person commits the offense of theft by receiving property stolen in another state when he receives, disposes of or retains stolen property which he knows or should know was stolen in another state, unless the property is received, disposed of or retained with intent to restore it to the owner. (Ord. 204 § 8, 1994) 9.32.090 - Theft by bringing stolen property into the state. A person commits the offense of theft by bringing stolen property into this state when he brings into this state any property which he knows or should know has been stolen in another state. (Ord. 204 § 9, 1994) 9.32.100 - Livestock theft. A. A person commits the offense of livestock theft when he unlawfully takes or, being in lawful possession thereof, unlawfully appropriates any livestock of another with the intention of depriving the owner of such livestock. B. For the purposes of this section, the term "livestock" means horses, cattle, swine, sheep, goats, rabbits, and any domestic animal produced as food for human consumption. C. Any person committing the offense of livestock theft where the fair market value of the livestock taken or appropriated is one hundred dollars or less, upon conviction, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. D. For the purposes of this section, if any livestock is killed or mutilated and a portion thereof taken, the value of the whole animal while alive or his entire carcass, whichever is greater, shall be considered for the purpose of distinguishing a misdemeanor offense. (Ord. 204 § 10, 1994) 9.32.110 - Removal or abandonment of shopping carts—Posting of code section in stores and markets. A. As used in this section, "shopping cart" means those pushcarts of the type which are commonly provided by grocery stores, drugstores, or other merchant stores or markets for the use of the public in transporting commodities in stores and markets and incidentally from the store to a place outside the store. B. It is unlawful for any person to remove a shopping cart from the premises, posted as provided in subsection D of this section, of the owner of such shopping cart without the consent, given at the time of such removal, of the owner or of his agent, servant or employee. For the purpose of this section, the premises shall include all the parking area set aside by the owner or on behalf of the owner for the parking of cars for the convenience of the patrons of the owner. C. It is unlawful for any person to abandon a shopping cart upon any public street, sidewalk, way or parking lot other than a parking lot on the premises of the owner. D. The owner of the store in which the shopping cart is used shall post in at least three prominent places in his store and at each exit therefrom a printed copy of this section, which copy shall be printed in type no smaller that twelve points. E. Any person who violates subsection B or C of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. (Ord. 204 § 11, 1994) 9.32.120 - Violation—Penalty. A. A person convicted of a violation of this chapter shall be punished as for a misdemeanor except: 1. If the property which was the subject of the theft was less than five hundred dollars in value, by imprisonment for not less than one day nor more than twelve months, in the discretion of the trial judge. Any sentence under this section may be suspended, stayed or probated, in the discretion of the trial judge. 2. The person convicted shall pay a fine of not less than two hundred fifty dollars on the first offense and five hundred dollars on the second conviction. Said fines shall be in addition to the appropriate surcharges and any restitution ordered by the court to the victim. Said fines and surcharges may be stayed, probated or suspended in the discretion of the trial court, however, the amount of restitution ordered to be paid to any victim shall not be suspended. (Ord. 204 § 12, 1994)

div.head: Chapter 9.36 - CURFEW
div.p:
Sections:
9.36.010 - Children on streets at night. It shall be unlawful for any person under eighteen years of age to be or remain upon any street or alley or other public place in the city between the hours of eleven p.m. until six a.m. Sunday through Thursday and between the hours of twelve a.m. until six a.m. Friday and Saturday unless such person is accompanied by a parent or guardian, or other person having custody of such minor or unless in the performance of duty directed by such parent or guardian or other person having custody or unless such person is in lawful employment making it necessary to be in such places during the designated hours. (Ord. 244 (part), 1998) 9.36.020 - Permitting children to violate curfew. It shall be unlawful for anyone having the legal care and custody of any person as described above to allow or permit such person to go or be upon any public street, alley or other public place in the city in the nighttime as restricted in the preceding section, except in case of necessity. (Ord. 244 (part), 1998) 9.36.030 - Delinquent children. If it shall appear that any child taken into custody for a violation of Section 9.36.010 is growing up in vagrancy, or is incorrigible, for lack of a proper parental care or has no home, proper proceedings shall be taken to have such child placed in the care of a state institution as provided by statute. (Ord. 244 (part), 1998) 9.36.040 - Penalties. Violations of this chapter by a minor shall be returned to the Barrow County Juvenile Court for disposition. Violations of this chapter by a parent, guardian or other person having the legal care and custody of a minor shall be a misdemeanor and shall be returned to the municipal court for disposition. Such violations shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars or thirty days in jail or both. (Ord. 244 (part), 1998)

div.head: Chapter 9.38 - FALSE ALARMS
div.p:
Sections:
9.38.010 - Definitions. A. For the purpose of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the respective meaning ascribed to them by this section: "Alarm" means any signal (audio or visual, recorded or live) transmitted to the county, indicating a predetermined condition exists when said alarm is received either: 1. By telephone line to the Barrow County 911 communications center or the city; 2. By a private alarm service company relayed to the Barrow County 911 communications center or the city's telephone; 3. By an automated telephone alarm system, playing a recorded message when received on the Barrow County 911 communications center's or the city's telephone 4. By an audible/visual sign relayed to the Barrow County 911 communications center or the city by a third party. "False alarm" means the activation of an alarm system where none of the emergencies for which the alarm system has been installed, have in fact occurred. "Telephone alarm system" means any alarm system, which automatically transmits by telephone line a recorded electronic or mechanical signal to a telephone instrument at the Barrow County 911 communications center or the city is prohibited. "Response" means the dispatch of any law enforcement or fire unit to the premises where an alarm has been activated. B. The installation and operation of equipment that will automatically dial in an alarm to the Barrow County 911 communications center or the city police department is prohibited. This does not include professional alarm companies that are supervised twenty-four hours a day, three hundred sixty-five days a year. (Ord. 269 (part), 2000) 9.38.020 - Prohibitions. It is unlawful for anyone to activate any robbery, burglary or fire alarm except in the event of an actual or attempted burglary, robbery or fire. It is unlawful for anyone to notify the city of an activated alarm with the knowledge that such activation was apparently caused by an electrical or other malfunction of the system of by lack of adequate maintenance of the alarm system without at the same time notifying the law enforcement of such apparent malfunctions. (Ord. 269 (part), 2000) 9.38.030 - Service fees imposed. A. For each response to a false alarm, a report shall be made and forwarded to the city police department. The city police shall take the following actions: 1. For the first false alarm from a premises within a six-month period, the city police shall forward to the property owner or premises lessee a copy of the report, a copy of this chapter and a statement that continued false alarms will lead to a service fee; 2. For the second false alarm from a premises within a twelve-month period, the city police shall suggest the alarm system to be inspected by a state licensed alarm low voltage contractor and to prescribe necessary corrective action (this will be done at the owners expense); 3. For the third false alarm within a twelve-month period, the property owner or lessee shall be charged a fee of fifty dollars; 4. For the fourth false alarm and all succeeding alarms within a twelve-month period, the property owner or lessee shall be charged a fee up to one hundred dollars per alarm and each additional alarm thereafter. B. The city police department shall be responsible for issuing citations for fees imposed. C. The false alarm shall not be considered for purposes of assessing a fee if: 1. Within ten days from the occurrence of a false alarm, the owner or lessee of the premises can demonstrate to the city police, as applicable, that the alarm system in question has actually been examined by an authorized repair service who certifies in writing that the system is currently in good working order; provided, however, no more than one letter may be submitted by an owner or lessee within six a month period in order to avoid a fee assessment; 2. The false alarm was not caused by employee error at a business location; 3. Notwithstanding the foregoing, no more than one such letter may be submitted by an owner or lessee of a premises within a twelve-month period in order to avoid a fee assessment as provided by this section; 4. The alarm was activated by inclement weather. (Ord. 269 (part), 2000)

div.head: Chapter 9.40 - ADOPTION BY REFERENCE OF STATE CODE PROVISIONS
div.p:
Sections:
9.40.010 - Criminal trespass. The mayor and city council adopt by reference the provisions of OCGA Section 16-7-21 as though fully set forth in this chapter verbatim. Violations of this section occurring within the city limits shall be returned to the municipal court for adjudication, pursuant to OCGA Section 36-32-10.1. (Ord. 275 (part), 2001) 9.40.020 - Interference with a police officer. The mayor and city council adopts by reference the provisions of OCGA Section l6-10-24(a) as though fully set forth in this chapter verbatim. Misdemeanor violations of this section occurring within the city limits shall be returned to the municipal court for adjudication. (Ord. 275 (part), 2001) 9.40.030 - Penalty. Violations of these provisions shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars and/or thirty days in jail. (Ord. 275 (part), 2001) Title 10 - VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC Chapters:

div.head: Chapter 10.02 - UNIFORM RULES OF THE ROAD AND JURISDICTION OF MUNICIPAL COURT
div.p:
Sections:
10.02.010 - Adoption by reference. Pursuant to OCGA Sections 40-6-372, 40-1-1 through 40-1-5 and 40-6-1 through 40-6-395, known as the Uniform Rules of the Road, are adopted as and for the traffic regulations of the city, as though fully set forth in this chapter. (Ord. 246 (part), 1998) 10.02.020 - Penalties. Unless another penalty is expressly provided by law, any person convicted of a violation of any provision of the OCGA sections stated in Section 10.05.010 shall be punished by a fine of not more than one thousand dollars or imprisonment for not more than one hundred eighty days or by both such fine and imprisonment. (Ord. 246 (part), 1998) 10.02.030 - Return of citations to municipal court. All citations issued within the corporate limits of the city shall be returned to the city for adjudication. (Ord. 246 (part), 1998)

div.head: Chapter 10.04 - TRAFFIC REGULATIONS
div.p:
Sections:
10.04.010 - Destructive equipment. It is unlawful for any person or persons to drive a tractor with lugs on the streets that are paved in the city or haul any equipment of any type that would disrupt or destroy the pavement of corporate limits of the city in any manner. Any person found guilty shall replace, repair or be responsible for the repair and be tried and fined as prescribed by ordinance. (Ord. 16, 1963)

div.head: Chapter 10.08 - ABANDONED, JUNKED AND INOPERATIVE VEHICLES
div.p:
Sections:
10.08.010 - Exterior storage of nonoperating vehicles. No person in charge of or in control of premises, whether as owner, lessee, tenant, occupant or otherwise, shall allow any more than two partially dismantled, wrecked, junked, discarded or otherwise nonoperating motor vehicles to remain on such property. This chapter shall further not apply with regard to any vehicle in an appropriate storage place or depository maintained in a lawful place and manner by the city or any other public agency or commercial entity. (Ord. 261 (part), 2000) 10.08.020 - Reconditioning of vehicles permitted. No inoperable/unregistered vehicles in excess of two shall be allowed, whether enclosed or not, on a residentially zoned property. One or two junked vehicles shall be allowed provided that the occupant of the home is in the process of reconditioning the vehicle(s) for his/her personal use and all other applicable standards are met. (Ord. 261 (part), 2000) 10.08.030 - Storage of vehicles and parts. All vehicles and parts of vehicles shall be stored out of view in a building or enclosure when not actually being repaired or restored. (Ord. 261 (part), 2000) 10.08.040 - Definition of abandoned junked and inoperable vehicle. For purposes of this chapter, a motor vehicle shall be deemed to be discarded, abandoned, dismantled, wrecked, scrapped, ruined, inoperable or junked personal property if it is not operational or exhibits any of the following characteristics: flat tires, no tires or wheels, parts missing from the body, interior or drivetrain of the vehicle. (Ord. 261 (part), 2000) 10.08.050 - Penalties. Violations of this chapter shall be returned by summons and citation, personally served, to the city for adjudication. Any conviction of a violation of this chapter shall be punished by a fine of not more than one thousand dollars or one year in jail. (Ord. 261 (part), 2000)

div.head: Chapter 10.12 - SPEED LIMITS AND SPEED ZONES
div.p:
Sections:
10.12.010 - Speed zones—On-system. Table 10.12.010 SPEED LIMITS AND SPEED ZONES—ON-SYSTEM STATE ROUTES
A. On-system signs only to be erected and maintained by the department of transportation. B. It is unlawful to use radar on any state route, county road or city street not in this section (Ga. Chapter 14 Section 40-14-3). C. Any unauthorized changes made to this section will cause it to be void. D. This section includes all construction/work zones on any state route posted with the statutory forty miles per hour speed limit. (Ord. No. 17-008, Exh. A, 12-7-17; Ord. No. 16-001, Exh. A, 2-4-2016; Ord. No. 13-001, Exh. A, 2-7-2013; Ord. 06-001 (part), 2006; Ord. 240 (part), 1998; Ord. 218 (part), 1995; Ord. 191 (part), 1993: Ord. 171 (part), 1993: Ord. 157 (part), 1992) 10.12.020 - Speed zones—Off-system. Table 10.12.020 SPEED LIMITS AND SPEED ZONES—OFF-SYSTEM LOCAL ROUTES
***School Zone Hours are Effective*** A.M. from forty-five minutes prior to commencement time to fifteen minutes after commencement time—School days only P.M. from fifteen minutes prior to dismissal time to forty-five minutes after dismissal time—School days only A. Signs to be erected and maintained by the city. B. It is unlawful to use radar on any state route, county road or city street not in this section (Ga. Chapt. 14, Sect. 40-14-03). C. Any unauthorized changes made to this section will cause it to be void. (Ord. No. 17-008, Exh. A, 12-7-17; Ord. No. 16-003, Exh. A, 1-6-17; Ord. No. 16-001, Exh. A, 2-4-2016; Ord. No. 13-001, Exh. A, 2-7-2013; Ord. 06-001 (part), 2006; Ord. 04-008, 2004; Ord. 240 (part), 1998; Ord. 218 (part), 1995; Ord. 191 (part), 1993: Ord. 171 (part), 1993: Ord. 157 (part), 1992) 10.12.030 - Maximum vehicle speeds. Table 10.12.030 SPEED LIMITS AND SPEED ZONES
A. The speed zones, as shown on Table 10.12.030, are established based on a traffic engineering investigation as required by Georgia law. B. Any unauthorized changes made to this section will cause it to be void in its entirety. This includes the removal, installation and/or relocation of signs erected on state right-of-way or any written changes made to this section. C. It is unlawful to use radar detection devices on any state route, county road or city street not listed on this section. D. This section includes all construction/work zones on any state route, county road or city street, as posted when signed in accordance with Georgia Code Section 40-06-188. E. Any person convicted of a violation of this section can be punished to the maximum as provided by Georgia law. (Ord. 05-008, 2005)

div.head: Chapter 10.14 - LIMITED ACCESS ON CERTAIN STREETS
div.p:
Sections:
10.14.010 - No through streets to truck traffic. It is unlawful to operate a truck greater than two tons on any city street unless, at intersection of such street with a state highway, signs are posted identifying such road as a designated local truck route and giving notice of the maximum weight limits for such designated local truck route. No truck above two tons shall use such streets as through street at anytime unless loading or unloading at a place of business or residence. (Ord. 257 (part), 1999) 10.14.020 - Penalties. Unless another penalty is expressly provided by law, any person convicted of violation of this chapter shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars and thirty days in jail. Citations for violation of this chapter shall be returned to the municipal court for adjudication. (Ord. 257 (part), 1999)

div.head: Chapter 10.16 - HEAVY VEHICLE PARKING
div.p:
Sections:
10.16.010 - Definition. "Heavy vehicle" means any large vehicle, cab, trailer, truck tractor trailer, bus or car carrier (including rollbacks and wreckers), including but not limited to school buses, in excess of nine hundred cubic feet or one-ton capacity. Recreational vehicles are specifically excluded from the definition of heavy vehicle; however, such vehicles shall not be parked on through streets or in any manner which would impede pedestrian or vehicular traffic or constitute a visual obstruction to motorists. (Ord. No. 13-007, 7-11-13) 10.16.020 - Parking hours. 1. It is unlawful for any person to permit or cause any vehicle to be parked or stored, for a period exceeding two hours on a commercial or industrial-zoned property unless: a. The vehicle is actually engaged in loading or unloading activity where the driver is present and in charge thereof; b. The vehicle is owned or is being used by a business located on the property for conducting business operations. 2. The prohibitions contained in this section shall be inapplicable to a truck stop or travel center which provides refueling, rest, parking, showers, ready-made food and other services to motorists and truck drivers. (Ord. No. 13-007, 7-11-13) 10.16.030 - Prohibited activities It is unlawful for any person to permit or cause any heavy vehicle to be used for sleeping, camping, or parking exceeding two hours in the following areas within the city, regardless of the zoning district in which it is located: a loading zone, a loading dock, a parking lot, a public street or roadway, or a private driveway in a residential district. (Ord. No. 13-007, 7-11-13) 10.16.040 - Jurisdiction The Municipal Court of the City of Auburn shall have jurisdiction to hear, try and dispose of citations that are issued for violations of this chapter. 1. Any vehicle owner or operator who violates the terms and conditions of this section shall be guilty of misdemeanor and subject to the penalties set forth in Section 4.13 of the Charter of the City of Auburn. 2. Each day such violation exists shall be deemed a separate offense. (Ord. No. 13-007, 7-11-13) 10.16.050 - Administration and service of process. Citations for violation of this article may be served by affixing the citation to the offending vehicle. Such citations shall notify the violator of his or her right to contest the citation in the municipal court and provide instructions for doing so. Whenever a person upon whose vehicle a citation is placed shall fail to report to municipal court in response to the notice, such person shall, upon conviction in the municipal court, be subject to a fine not less than fifty dollars nor more than one thousand dollars in the discretion of the court. (Ord. No. 13-007, 7-11-13) Title 12 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC PLACES Chapters:

div.head: Chapter 12.08 - PUBLIC PARKS
div.p:
Sections:
12.08.010 - Code provisions extended to parks. All laws, provisions of this code, and other ordinances in force in the city for the promotion of the peace, good order and morals thereof, are, whenever applicable, extended to and shall embrace the territory included in the public parks, and any person violating any such ordinance shall be subject to the penalties therefor provided in this code. (Ord. 63A § 10-2, 1977) 12.08.020 - Protection of plant and animal life on public and private property. It is unlawful for any person to molest, injure or destroy foliage, plants, shrubs, flowers, trees, birds, bird nests, squirrels, or rabbits in or upon any public park, public property, or the property of another, without the permission of the owner, as to private property, or the director of the bureau of parks, as to the property of the city. (Ord. 63A § 10-5, 1977) 12.08.030 - Posting bills and notices. Any person who, in any park, shall post bills or notices shall be guilty of an offense and shall be punished as provided in this code; provided, however, that the director of parks may allow bills and/or notice signs to be temporarily placed in any park when, in the discretion of the director, such sign will be beneficial to any municipal or public endeavor, athletic or otherwise. (Ord. 63A § 10-3, 1977) 12.08.040 - Dogs prohibited in parks. It is unlawful for any person to permit such person's dog within the limits of public parks. (Ord. 63A § 10-4, 1977) 12.08.050 - Penalty for persistent violation of rules. Any person who shall persist in the violation of any of the rules and regulations prescribed for the government of the parks, after notice to desist from so doing, shall, on conviction thereof by the judge of the municipal court, be punished as provided by city ordinance. (Ord. 63A § 10-1, 1977)

div.head: Chapter 12.12 - CEMETERY
div.p:
Sections:
12.12.010 - City to govern property. The city shall govern the property of the city's cemetery. As the city is the sole owner of the property the city has authorized the issuance of up to eight four × ten lots to each family. Under extenuating circumstances the mayor and council shall have the sole right to approve the sale of additional lots above the maximum number identified in this section. (Ord. 61 (part), 1976) (Ord. No. 09-019, 5-5-09) 12.12.020 - Permit. The person requiring a lot in the above-mentioned cemetery shall obtain a written permit of approval. The permit shall be issued by the city clerk's office until such time that a cemetery committee is appointed. (Ord. 61 (part), 1976) 12.12.030 - Applicability of chapter. This chapter shall pertain to the part of the cemetery already established. The new part of the cemetery shall be divided into lots and sold. Money derived from the sale of the property shall be used solely for the upkeep of the cemetery. (Ord. 61 (part), 1976) 12.12.040 - Violation—Penalty. Any violation of the terms of this chapter shall be punished as provided under Section 28 of the Charter of the city and under Ordinance Number One of the Town of Auburn. (Ord. 61 (part), 1976)

div.head: Chapter 12.16 - PARADES
div.p:
Sections:
12.16.010 - Title. The title of this chapter shall be known and may be cited as the "parade ordinance of the city of Auburn, Georgia." (Ord. 144 § 1, 1992) 12.16.020 - Definitions. As used in this chapter: City. The words "the city" or "this city" shall be construed as if the words "of Auburn" followed. "Float" means a vehicle with a platform attached that is used to carry people and/or some type of exhibit or display during a parade. "Parade" means any march, ceremony, demonstration, show, exhibition, pageant or procession of any kind consisting of people, animals, vehicles, or any combination thereof, in or upon any public street, sidewalk, park, or public place within the city. "Permittee" means the person that is responsible for the overall organization and conduct of the parade. "Person" means associations, firms, partnerships, political bodies, and corporate entities, as well as individuals. "Public place" means and includes any park, cemetery, school yard or open space adjacent thereto, any lake or stream, or any place which, from its public character, members of the general public frequent, or where they may be expected to congregate at any time as a matter of common right; also, any place at which, even though it is privately owned or controlled, a number of persons have assembled through common usage or by invitation, either express or implied. "Sidewalk" means any portion of a street between the curb line and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians, excluding parkways. "Street" means and includes not only streets but also highways, avenues, boulevards, roads, alleys, lanes, and all other public ways located in the city. "Unit" means any and all participants including, but not limited to, people, animals, vehicles and floats. "Vehicle" means any type of self-propelled automotive vehicle with rubber tires designed for use on any roadway. (Ord. 144 § 3, 1992) 12.16.030 - Exemptions. This chapter shall not apply to the following: 1. Funeral processions. (Ord. 144 § 4, 1992) 12.16.040 - Permit—Application. A. Generally. Any person seeking to conduct a parade within the city shall file an application with the chief of police of the city. These application forms are provided by the city and may be obtained in the office of the clerk. B. Filing Period. An application for a parade permit shall be filed with the chief of police not less than thirty days nor more than ninety days prior to the date of the proposed parade. C. Late Applications. If an application for a permit to conduct a parade is filed less than thirty days prior to the proposed date of the parade, the chief of police has the discretion to refuse to consider the application if there is insufficient time to make adequate arrangements for the proper and safe conduct of the proposed parade. D. Request for Waiver of Filing Period Time Limitation. If an applicant fails to file an application for a parade permit within the required time period and the chief of police refuses to consider such application, he or she may request a waiver of this requirement by the city council for the city by appearing at the next regular meeting of the city council or at a special meeting called by the council to specifically consider this matter. The city council may then exercise its discretion and waive the requirement with regard to the filing period. E. Content of Applications.
