The application for a parade permit shall contain the following information: 1. The name, address and telephone number of the applicant; 2. The name, address and telephone number of the parade leader or the person otherwise responsible for the overall organization and conduct of the parade; 3. The name, address and telephone number of the headquarters and officers of any sponsoring organization(s), if the proposed parade is to be conducted for, on behalf of, or by this organization; 4. The proposed date of the parade as well as any potential alternative date(s) for the proposed parade; 5. The purpose of the proposed parade; 6. The location of the assembly or starting area, the route to be traveled, and the location of the termination or disbanding area; 7. The time at which the parade will begin to assemble as well as the time at which the parade will start and terminate; 8. The approximate number of persons, animals, floats and/or vehicles that will constitute the proposed parade; 9. The interval of space to be maintained between the units of the parade; 10. A description of the individual floats, vehicles, marching units, musical bands, and/or animals that will constitute the proposed parade; 11. A listing of any and all commercial, private or nonprofit organizations or entities that will be represented in the proposed parade; 12. A description of any sound amplification equipment intended for use in the proposed parade; 13. A statement as to whether the parade will occupy all or only a portion of the width of the public street(s) to be traveled in the proposed parade route; 14. If the parade is to be held by, for, or on behalf of any person other than the applicant for the permit, then the applicant shall file a written statement from the person proposing to hold the parade authorizing the applicant to seek the parade permit on his/her behalf. F. The applicant agrees to supplement the above information with additional material that the chief of police finds reasonably necessary to determine whether a permit should be issued. (Ord. 144 § 5, 1992) 12.16.050 - Permit—Standards for issuance or denial. The chief of police shall issue a parade permit, if, upon considering the application and any information otherwise obtained, he determines in his discretion that: A. The size or nature of the proposed parade will not require the diversion of so great a number of police officers of the city, for the purpose of controlling and monitoring the parade, that allowing the parade would prevent reasonable police protection of the city; B. The concentration of the persons, vehicles, floats and animals at the assembly point(s) of the proposed parade will not unduly interfere with the ability of the public safety agencies to provide the proper fire and police protection and ambulance services to those areas near these assembly point(s); C. The proposed parade will not interfere with any other parade for which a permit has been previously issued; D. The conduct of the proposed parade is not reasonably likely to cause injury to persons or property or to otherwise provoke disorderly conduct or create a disturbance; E. The proposed parade will move at a fixed rate of speed without reasonable delays en route to its termination point; F. The amplification of sound permitted from sound trucks, amplifiers, bullhorns, or other similar equipment will remain fixed at a reasonable level as established by the chief of police and/or at a level provided for by ordinance; and G. The materials used in the construction of the floats in the proposed parade comply with any fire safety or prevention requirements imposed by law. (Ord. 144 § 6, 1992) 12.16.060 - Permit—Administrative/processing fee. The administrative fee necessary to cover the cost of processing the application for a parade permit is fifty dollars. This fee is nonrefundable and is to be paid to the chief of police in advance of the issuance of any parade permit. (Ord. 144 § 7, 1992) 12.16.070 - Permit—Notice of denial. The chief of police shall act upon any application for a parade permit within ten days after the timely filing of the application with the office of the chief of police. If the application is denied, the chief of police shall mail a notice of his denial of the permit to the applicant within ten days after such application is filed. The reason(s) for the denial of the permit shall be stated within the notice forwarded to the applicant by the chief of police. (Ord. 144 § 8, 1992) 12.16.080 - Alternative permit. In denying an application for a parade permit, the chief of police may propose and thereafter authorize a different date, time or route from that requested on the application for the permit. The chief of police may also place any necessary conditions or restrictions on the vehicles and participants of the parade in order to provide for the safety and general welfare of the parade participants, bystanders, and all other members of the general public during the conduct of the parade. An applicant that desires to accept the alternative permit, without exception, as proposed by the chief of police shall file a written notice of acceptance with the chief of police within five days after the mailing of the notice of the denial of the application for the proposed parade permit. (Ord. 144 § 9, 1992) 12.16.090 - Appeal procedure. Upon denial of an application for a parade permit by the chief of police, the applicant may appeal the decision denying the permit to the city council. A written notice of appeal shall be filed with the clerk within thirty days after the notice of denial is mailed to the applicant. Upon appeal, the city council may reverse, affirm or otherwise modify the decision rendered by the chief of police. The council shall thereafter notify the police chief of its decision and, if necessary, shall direct the police chief to issue a parade permit in accordance with its decision. (Ord. 144 § 10, 1992) 12.16.100 - Notice to city and other officials. Immediately following the issuance of a parade permit, the chief of police shall send a copy of the permit to the following individuals: A. The mayor; B. The city clerk; C. The fire chief of the Auburn-Barrow fire department; D. The Barrow County sheriff's department; and E. The city attorney. (Ord. 144 § 11, 1992) 12.16.110 - Permit—Contents. The following information shall be specified in each parade permit issued by the chief of police: A. The specific area in which the parade is to assemble and the time at which the parade participants will begin to assemble; B. The starting time of the parade; C. The route of the parade; D. The minimum and maximum speeds of the parade; E. The specific portion(s) of the width of the streets that will be utilized during the parade; F. The minimum and maximum intervals of space to be maintained between the various units of the parade; G. The maximum number of units that may be contained in the parade; H. The maximum length of the parade in miles or fractions thereof; I. The disbanding area and the approximate time at which the parade will disband; and J. A statement that the applicant/permittee is required to comply with each and every term or condition contained within the parade permit; K. Any other information or conditions that the chief of police shall determine is necessary in order to provide for the protection of persons or property within the city during the conduct of a parade. (Ord. 144 § 12, 1992) 12.16.120 - Duties of permittee. A. The permittee shall comply with all of the directions and conditions contained in the parade permit, all of the provisions contained within this chapter and all other ordinances of the city, and all applicable state laws; B. The permittee shall assure that the parade leader, or any other such person responsible for conducting the parade, carries the parade permit upon his or her person at all times during the conduct of the parade; and C. The permittee shall provide all parade participants with written notice of the terms and conditions contained within the permit. Such notice is to be provided to all participants prior to the conduct of the parade. (Ord. 144 § 13, 1992) 12.16.130 - Revocation of permit. The chief of police has the authority to revoke any parade permit issued pursuant to this chapter when, upon applying the standards for issuance, he finds that revocation is necessary in order to provide for the protection of persons and property located within the city. (Ord. 144 § 14, 1992) 12.16.140 - Public conduct during parades. A. Interference. No person shall unreasonably hamper, obstruct, impede or otherwise interfere with any parade or parade assembly or with any person, vehicle, float or animal participating or otherwise utilized in a parade. B. Driving Through Parades. No driver of a vehicle or rider of an animal shall proceed between the vehicles, persons, animals or other units comprising a parade when such units are in motion and are conspicuously designated as a parade. C. Parking on Parade Route. The chief of police may prohibit or otherwise restrict the parking of any vehicle(s) along any street, park or public place that constitutes a part of the route of the parade. If necessary, the chief of police shall post signs to this effect, and it is unlawful for any person to park or leave unattended any vehicle in violation of this prohibition. (Ord. 144 § 15, 1992) 12.16.150 - Violation—Penalty—Enforcement. A. Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to a fine upon conviction in the municipal court. The fine imposed under this chapter shall not exceed one thousand dollars per offense. B. Citations under this chapter shall be issued by the police department ordering those cited to appear before the municipal court at a designated date and time. C. It shall be the responsibility of the police department to enforce this chapter. (Ord. 144 § 16, 1992) 12.16.160 - Interpretation. Whenever in this chapter it is provided that a decision is to be made within the discretion of the police chief, or any other officer or official of the city, this shall be construed to give such official(s) only the discretion of determining whether the duties, rules and standards established by this chapter have been complied with. No such provision shall be construed as giving any officer discretionary powers to determine what such duties, regulations or standards shall be or the power to require conditions not prescribed by the chapter or the power to enforce the chapter provisions in any arbitrary or discriminatory manner. (Ord. 144 § 17, 1992)

div.head: Chapter 12.20 - STREET TREES
div.p:
Sections:
12.20.010 - Definitions. "Street trees" means trees, shrubs, bushes, and all other woody vegetation on land lying between property lines on either side of all streets, avenues or ways within the city. (Ord. 190 § 1, 1993) 12.20.020 - City tree board—Creation and establishment. There is created and established a city tree board for the city of Auburn, Georgia, which shall consist of five members, citizens and residents of this city, who shall be appointed by the mayor with the approval of the city council. (Ord. 190 § 2, 1993) 12.20.030 - Term of office for board members. The term of the five persons to be appointed by the mayor shall be three years except that the term of two of the members appointed of the first board shall be for two years. In the event that a vacancy shall occur during the term of any member, his successor shall be appointed for the unexpired portion of the term. (Ord. 190 § 3, 1993) 12.20.040 - Compensation for board members. Members of the board shall serve without compensation. (Ord. 190 § 4, 1993) 12.20.050 - Duties and responsibilities of board. It shall be the responsibility of the board to study, investigate, counsel, and develop and/or update annually, and administer a written plan for the care, preservation, pruning, planting, replanting, removal or disposition of trees and shrubs, along streets and in other public areas. Such plan will be presented annually to the city council and upon their acceptance and approval shall constitute the official comprehensive city of Auburn tree plan. The board, when requested by the city council, shall consider, investigate, make finding, report and recommend upon any special matter of question coming within the scope of its work. (Ord. 190 § 5, 1993) 12.20.060 - Operation of board. The board shall choose its own officers, make its own rules and regulations and keep a journal of its proceedings. A majority of the members shall be a quorum for the transaction of business. (Ord. 190 § 6, 1993) 12.20.070 - List of trees. The tree board shall make a list of desirable and undesirable trees to plant in the city. These should be listed as small, medium and large trees. (Ord. 190 § 7, 1993) 12.20.080 - Spacing of trees. The spacing of street trees may not be closer together than the following: small trees, thirty feet; medium trees, forty feet; large trees, fifty feet; except in special plantings designed or approved by a landscape architect. (Ord. 190 § 8, 1993) 12.20.090 - Distance from curb and sidewalk. The distance trees may be planted from the curbs or curblines and sidewalks shall not be closer than the following: small trees, two feet; medium trees, three feet; large trees, four feet. (Ord. 190 § 9, 1993) 12.20.100 - Distance from street corners and fire hydrants. No street tree shall be planted closer than thirty-five feet from any street corner, measured from the point of nearest intersecting curbs or curblines. No street tree shall be planted closer than ten feet from any fire hydrant. (Ord. 190 § 10, 1993) 12.20.110 - Utilities. No street tree may be planted under or within ten lateral feet of any overhead utility wire, or over or within five feet of any underground water line, sewer line, transmission line or other utility. (Ord. 190 § 11, 1993) 12.20.120 - Public tree care. A. The city shall have the right to plant, prune, maintain and remove trees, plants and shrubs within the lines of all streets, alleys, avenues and public grounds, as may be necessary to insure public safety or to preserve or enhance the symmetry and beauty of such public grounds. B. The city tree board may remove or cause or order to be removed, any tree or part thereof which is in an unsafe condition or which by reason of its nature is injurious to sewers, electric power lines, gas lines, water lines, or other public improvements, or is affected with any injurious fungus, insect or other pest. This section does not prohibit the planting of street trees by adjacent property owners providing that the selection and location of said trees is in accordance with Sections 12.20.070 through 12.20.100 of this chapter. (Ord. 190 § 12, 1993) 12.20.130 - Tree topping. It is unlawful as a normal practice for any person, firm or city department to top any street tree, park tree, or other tree on public property. "Topping" is defined as the severe cutting back of limbs to stubs larger than three inches in diameter within the tree's crown to such a degree so as to remove the normal canopy and disfigure the tree. Trees severely damaged by storms or other causes, or certain trees under utility wires or other obstructions where other pruning practices are impractical may be exempted from this chapter at the determination of the city tree board. (Ord. 190 § 13, 1993) 12.20.140 - Pruning, corner clearance. Every owner of any tree overhanging any street or right-of-way within the city shall prune the branches so that such branches shall not obstruct the light from any streetlight or obstruct the view of any street intersection and so that there shall be a clear space of eight feet above the surface of the street or sidewalk. Said owners shall remove all dead, diseased or dangerous trees, or broken or decayed limbs which constitute a menace to the safety of the public. The city shall have the right to prune any tree or shrub on private property when it interferes with the proper spread of light along the street from a streetlight or interferes with visibility of any traffic-control device or sign. (Ord. 190 § 14, 1993) 12.20.150 - Removal of dead or diseased trees. The city shall have the right to cause the removal of any dead or diseased trees on private property within the city, when such trees constitute a hazard to life and property, or harbor insects or disease which constitute a potential threat to other trees within the city. The city tree board will notify in writing the owners of such trees. Removal shall be done by said owners at their own expense within sixty days after the date of service of notice. In the event of failure of owners to comply with such provisions, the city shall have the authority to remove such trees and charge the cost of removal to the owners. (Ord. 190 § 15, 1993) 12.20.160 - Interference with city tree board. It is unlawful for any person to prevent, delay or interfere with the city tree board, or any of its agents, while engaging in and about the planting, cultivating, mulching, pruning, spraying or removing of any street trees, park trees or trees on private grounds, as authorized in this chapter. (Ord. 190 § 16, 1993) 12.20.170 - Arborists license and bond. It is unlawful for any person or firm to engage in the business or occupation of pruning, treating or removing street or park trees within the city without first procuring a license. The license fee shall be paid annually in advance; provided, however, that no license shall be required of any public service company or city employee doing such work in the pursuit of their public service endeavors. Before any license shall be issued, each applicant shall first file evidence of possession of liability and bodily injury insurance in the minimum amounts of fifty thousand dollars and one hundred thousand dollars property damage indemnifying the city of any personal injury or damage resulting from the pursuit of such endeavors as herein described. (Ord. 190 § 17, 1993) 12.20.180 - Review by city council. The city council shall have the right to review the conduct, acts, and decisions of the city tree board. Any person may appeal from any ruling or order of the city tree board to the city council who may hear the matter and make a final decision. (Ord. 190 § 18, 1993) 12.20.190 - Violation—Penalty. Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be, upon conviction or a plea of guilty, subject to a fine not to exceed one hundred dollars. (Ord. 190 § 20, 1993)

div.head: Chapter 12.21 - BUILDING NUMBERING
div.p:
Sections:
12.21.010 - Assignment. Street numbers for dwelling units and places of business on all public streets and street numbers and/or building numbers for dwelling units and places of business within apartments/condominiums and nonresidential developments located on private streets shall be assigned by the city. (Ord. 03-007 (part), 2003) 12.21.020 - One- and two-family dwelling unit requirements. Each one- and two-family unit shall have posted and maintained in a conspicuous place on the property, visible from the street providing general public access, the address of the dwelling unit in figures at least three inches high on a contrasting background that will allow twenty-four-hour visibility. (Ord. 03-007 (part), 2003) 12.21.030 - Multifamily requirements. Each multifamily building with three or more dwelling units shall have posted and maintained in a conspicuous place on the building, visible from the parking lot or street providing general public access, the addresses or numbers of the building in figures at least six inches high on a contrasting background and each individual apartment/unit within the building shall be marked on or about its main entrance with the individual apartment/unit number and/or address in figures at least three inches high on a contrasting background that will allow twenty-four-hour visibility. In addition to these requirements, where a multifamily building has more than one exterior entrance, each of the entrance shall be marked, in figures at least three inches high on a contrasting background, with the number and/or address of each and every individual apartment/unit to which access is provided through that common entrance. (Ord. 03-007 (part), 2003) 12.21.040 - Business and other nonresidential building requirements. Each business or other nonresidential building shall have posted and maintained in a conspicuous place on the property, visible from the street providing public access, the address of the building in figures at least three inches high on a contrasting background that will allow twenty-four-hour visibility. If the numbers are not placed within fifteen feet of the back of the street curbing or edge of the street surface, then the figures shall be at least six inches high. A quadrant designation will be posted as part of the address in figures at least two inches high on a contrasting background of a material that will allow twenty-four-hour visibility and be placed with the number designation. (Ord. 03-007 (part), 2003) 12.21.050 - Display during construction. Building numbers shall be continuously displayed from the issuance of the building permit through the issuance of a certificate of occupancy. All persons shall refer to the street numbers when contacting the city code and building inspection staff. (Ord. 03-007 (part), 2003) 12.21.060 - Violation. Failure to display numbers as required by this chapter shall constitute a violation of this portion of the city code of ordinances. Any person convicted of violating this chapter shall be subject to a fine of not less than one hundred dollars and not more than one thousand dollars. Citations for violation of this chapter shall be returned to the city of Auburn Municipal Court. (Ord. 03-007 (part), 2003) 12.21.070 - Enforcement. The city of Auburn police department and code enforcement officer shall be charged with the enforcement of this chapter. (Ord. 03-007 (part), 2003) 12.21.080 - Conflict. All ordinances or parts of ordinances which conflict with this chapter and the applicable code are repealed. Should any portion of this chapter be determined to be unconstitutional or unenforceable by a court of competent jurisdiction, the rest and remainder of this chapter shall remain in full force and effect. (Ord. 03-007 (part), 2003) 12.21.090 - Effective date. This chapter and the authority granted by and through it shall become effective immediately upon its adoption by the mayor and council of the city. (Ord. 03-007 (part), 2003)

div.head: Chapter 12.24 - COMPENSATION APPLICABLE TO TELEGRAPH OR TELEPHONE COMPANIES
div.p: 12.24.001 - Due compensation for telephone companies with end user retail customers within the city. A. The city hereby requires due compensation of three percent of actual recurring local service revenues, as defined in paragraphs (8) and (9) of O.C.G.A. § 46-5-1(b); provided, however, that any company which pays in excess of three percent of actual recurring local service revenues pursuant to an existing franchise agreement shall continue to pay in accordance with the agreement until the expiration of the franchise agreement or December 31, 2012, whichever occurs first, and any company which pays in excess of three percent of actual recurring local service revenues in accordance with an occupational license tax arrangement shall continue to pay in accordance with such payment schedule until December 31, 2012. B. Regarding any telephone company that does not have retail, end user customers located within the city's municipal boundaries, the payment by such company to a municipal authority in accordance with the rates set by regulations promulgated by the department of transportation for the use of its rights-of-way shall be considered the payment of due compensation. (Ord. No. 09-017, § 1, 2-5-09) 12.24.002 - Authorized designee. The city administrator shall, on behalf of the city, exercise day-to-day administrative duties necessary to fulfill the regulatory authority of the city under O.C.G.A. § 46-5-1 et seq. and shall perform the following duties: A. Review application information submitted by a telephone company to the city and, if an application is incomplete, notify the telegraph or telephone company within fifteen business days of the receipt of such application, identifying in such notice all application deficiencies. B. Report the receipt of a completed application to the council within sixty calendar days of the receipt of such completed application. C. Review payments of due compensation submitted by the company to ensure compliance with the provisions of the amended law and this chapter. D. Provide a coordination function between a telephone company and all city departments on any matter relating to the amended law and this chapter. E. Arrange and evaluate, no more than once a year, a comprehensive review of the records of a company which is reasonably related to the calculation and payment of due compensation. F. Provide to all telegraph and telephone companies located in its rights of way written notice of annexations and changes in municipal corporate boundaries. (Ord. No. 09-017, § 2, 2-5-09) Title 13 - PUBLIC SERVICES Chapters:

div.head: Chapter 13.04 - WATER SYSTEM
div.p:
Sections:
13.04.010 - Meter readings—Billings—Collecting. A. Bills to customers for water shall be mailed out on such day or days of each month as may be determined as desirable by the city. Bills shall be paid at city hall. A failure to receive bills or notices shall not prevent the city from demanding payment of same. The failure of water users to pay charges duly imposed may result in the imposition of the following penalties: 1. Nonpayment by the due date will subject the account to a penalty of ten percent of the delinquent amounts. 2. On the first day following the due date of an unpaid account, after posting payments received by mail or night deposit, late fees shall be assessed and written notice of such delinquency and assessment shall be mailed to the water customer or posted at the water service address. On the tenth day following the due date of an unpaid account, after posting payments received by mail or night deposit, water service will be cut off if the account remains unpaid. Notice will be given of the cut off and of the fees which will be charged in order to have service reconnected. 3. If water service is disconnected for nonpayment of an account, such service will only be restored after the unpaid bill(s) are paid in full, a security deposit, as may be required by the mayor and council, is made, and a service charge is paid for each meter to be reconnected. See Rate Schedule. 4. Should the water customer elect to pay the delinquent account on the date set for cutoff, a collection fee will be charged. See Rate Schedule. B. The reconnection fee applies only to service which is reconnected during the hours of eight a.m. to five p.m., Monday through Friday. Should the reconnection be made outside these hours, the reconnection charge will be increased according to the Rate Schedule in this chapter. C. Should any check written for the payment of a delinquent water account be returned to the city as "unpaid", "insufficient funds", "do not resubmit" or with any other markings indicating that the check will not be honored for the face amount, in addition to any applicable fees, fines or penalties, water service shall be disconnected without notice until all balances, penalties and reconnect fees due are paid in full. All further payments on said account must be made by cash or money order after the second occurrence of a check being returned. Payments by check will no longer be accepted on said account. (Ord. 252 § 2, 1998; Ord. 224 § 1, 2, 3, 1996; Ord. 177 § 1, 1994) 13.04.020 - Access to premises and extensions of systems. A. Officials, employees and duly authorized agents of the city of Auburn shall have access at all hours to the premises of the water customer for the purpose of installing or removing city property, inspecting piping, reading and testing meters, or for any other purpose in connection with the installation, maintenance and/or operation of the city of Auburn water system and its facilities. B. Extensions to the system shall be made only when the customer shall grant or convey, or shall cause to be granted or conveyed to the city of Auburn a permanent easement of right-of-way across any property traversed by the water lines. (Ord. 177 § 2, 1994) 13.04.030 - Suspension of service. When water service is discontinued and all bills paid, the security deposit mandated by Section 13.04.100 of this chapter, if applicable to the customer, shall be refunded to the water customer by the city. A. Upon discontinuance of service for nonpayment of bills, the security deposit, if applicable to the customer, as required by Section 13.04.100 of this chapter will be applied by the city of Auburn towards settlement of the account. Any balance will be refunded to the consumer; however, if the security deposit is insufficient to cover bills, the city may proceed to collect the balance due in the usual way provided for by law or in such other method as may be authorized by the city charter as now or hereafter amended, by state law or pursuant to ordinances adopted by the city. B. The city reserves the right to discontinue its water service without notice for the following reasons: 1. To prevent fraud or abuse; 2. Because of a water customer's continued wilful disregard of rules and regulations affecting the city's water system; 3. To conduct emergency repairs; 4. Because of an insufficient water supply; 5. Because of legal processes; 6. At the direction of other governmental or public authorities; 7. Because of strike, riot, fire, flood or an unavoidable accident; and 8. To prevent contamination of the public water system due to possible cross-connection when requested to do so by city personnel or when it is necessary to protect the water system or individual properties from cross-connection or backflow situations. (Ord. 177 § 3, 1994) 13.04.040 - Complaints—Adjustment. If a water customer believes his/her bill to be in error, he/she shall present his/her claim, in person, to the appropriate employees at city hall before the bill becomes delinquent. Such claim, if made after the bill has become delinquent shall not be effective in preventing discontinuance of service as heretofore provided. The water customer may pay such bill under protest and said payment shall not prejudice his/her claim that the charges contained on the bill are erroneous. A. The city will make a special water meter reading at the request of a water customer for a fee of five dollars; provided, however, that if such special reading discloses that the meter was overread, no charge will be made. B. Water meters will be tested at the request of a water customer upon payment to the city of the actual costs to make the test; provided, however, that if the meter is found to overregister beyond three percent of the correct volume, no charge will be made. C. If the seal of meter is broken by other than the city's officials, employees or authorized representatives or if the meter fails to register correctly or is stopped for any cause, the consumer shall pay an amount estimated from the record of his/her previous bills and/or from other proper data. There is a one hundred dollar tampering fee for meters turned on after being turned off by the city for nonpayment, whether locked or unlocked. (Ord. 177 § 4, 1994) 13.04.050 - Water customer's responsibility and liability. Water furnished by the city of Auburn shall be used for consumption by the water customer, members of his/her household and employees only. The water customer shall not sell water to any other person or permit any other person to use said water. Water shall not be used for irrigation, fire protection or other purposes except when water is available in sufficient quantity without interfering with the regular domestic consumption in the area served. Disregard of this rule shall be sufficient cause for a refusal and/or discontinuance of service. A. Where a meter or a meter box is placed on the premises of a water customer, a suitable place shall be provided by the water customer, thereon, unobstructed and accessible at all times to authorized representatives of the city. B. The water customer shall furnish and maintain a private cut-off valve on the customer's side of the meter. The water customer's piping and other required apparatus shall be installed and maintained by the water customer at the customer's expense, in a safe and efficient manner, and in compliance with the sanitary regulations of the State Health Department and applicable plumbing codes. C. In order to be accepted as a water customer and entitled to receive water from the city's water system, all applicants, as provided in Section 13.04.100, must offer proof that any private wells located on their property are not physically connected to the lines of the city's water system and all applicants by becoming customers of the city's water system covenant and agree that so long as they continue to be customers of the city, they will not permit the connection of any private wells on their property to the city's water system. (Ord. 177 § 5, 1994) 13.04.060 - Reserved. 13.04.070 - Charges constituting lien. A. The charges for water shall be a lien upon the premises as provided for in the charter of the city. Whenever a bill for water service remains unpaid sixty days after it has been rendered, the city clerk may file with the clerk of the Superior Court of Barrow County, a statement of lien claim. This statement shall contain a legal description of the premises served, the amount of the unpaid bill, and a notice that the city claims a lien for this amount as well as for all charges for water service subsequent to the period covered by the bill. (Ord. 224 § 4, 1996; Ord. 177 § 6b, 1994) 13.04.080 - Foreclosure of lien. Property subject to a lien for unpaid water bills, as provided for in Section 13.04.070, may be sold for nonpayment of same, and the proceeds of such sale shall be applied to pay the delinquent accounts, after deducting costs, as in the case of the foreclosure of statutory liens. Such foreclosure shall be by the appropriate provision of the charter of the city of Auburn or under the authority of state law, and any action will be brought in the name of the city. This section does not obligate the city to pursue this avenue when collecting delinquent water accounts and thus the city may use any other appropriate legal measures to collect such delinquent accounts. (Ord. 177 § 6c, 1994) 13.04.090 - Water rate schedule. A. From and after the passage of the ordinance codified in this chapter, there is adopted the following water rate schedule for the city of Auburn, Georgia: MONTHLY WATER RATE SCHEDULE Inside City Limits—Residential Service Charges for residential service inside the city limits shall be made according to the following schedule (Base Rate: $ 10.00):
Outside City Limits and Non-Residential Uses Charges for service to non-residential uses and those outside the city limits shall be made according to the following schedule (Base Rate: $ 15.00):
The foregoing rates shall take effect November 1, 2001. B. All future revisions to this rate schedule shall be made by resolution of the mayor and city council approved in a public meeting and identified in the minutes of said meeting. The rate schedule shall be reviewed at least annually and revised as needed to provide for the receipt of adequate revenues to meet requirements of the operation and maintenance of the system, debt service, if any, and the establishment of necessary reserves. No free service or use of the facilities shall be permitted, and all water service connections shall be metered. (Ord. 264 § 1, 2001) 13.04.100 - Application for water service. A. Any individual who is the owner of the premises seeking water service shall make application for such service, in person, at the city hall. B. Any individual seeking water service shall make application for such service in person at the city hall and shall pay simultaneously a cash security deposit for water service according to the rate schedule in this chapter. (Ord. 252 § 3, 1998; Ord. 224 § 7, 1996; Ord. 177 § 8, 1994) 13.04.110 - Charges for initial water service. Each water customer subscribing for the first time to use the water service of the city of Auburn shall pay a connection fee (meter installation fee) for each such connection desired according to the following schedule based upon meter size: RATE SCHEDULE Water Charges*
* Bills paid after the sixteenth of the month will have ten percent added to account. Bills paid after five p.m. on the twenty-fifth of the month will have twenty-five dollars added to account. Meter Installation Charges* Inside Subdivision: $600.00 Outside Subdivision:
* Three-inch through sixteen-inch meters are furnished and installed by developer. No water connection shall be made until the applicable connection fees shall have been first paid to the city and any form or forms as may be required by the city, from time to time, have been executed requesting the installation of said meter and service connection. Said forms shall identify the property which is to be served. The fees to connect meters of these sizes will be set by the mayor and council at the time application is made. B. Any individual who is not the owner of the premises, including, but not limited o renters, tenants or lessees, seeking water service shall make application for such service in person at the city hall, and shall pay simultaneously a cash security deposit for water service according to the rate schedule in this chapter. (Ord. 264 § 1, 2001; Ord. 252 § 3, 1998; Ord. 224 § 7, 1996; Ord. 177, 1994) 13.04.120 - Minimum charges. The minimum charge, as provided in the rate schedule, shall be made for such connections subscribed for. Water furnished for a given property shall be used on that property only. (Ord. 177 § 10, 1994) 13.04.130 - City's responsibility and liability. The city shall run a service line from its distribution line to the property line of a proposed water customer if such a distribution line is present or is to be constructed and if said distribution line runs immediately adjacent to or parallel to the property of the water customer to be served. No service charge other than the connection fee referred to in Section 13.04.110 will be made for a five-eighths-inch or three-quarters-inch meter. A proportionately greater charge than the connection fee will be made for meters of larger dimensions according to the fees set by the city. A. The city may make connections to service other properties not adjacent to its distribution lines upon payment of the reasonable costs for the extension of its distribution lines as may be required to render such service. B. The city reserves the right to install its water meters at or near the property line of a water customer or, at the city's option, on the customer's property within three feet of the property line. C. The city reserves the right to refuse service to any proposed water customer unless the proposed customer's lines or piping are installed in such a manner as to prevent cross-connections or backflow. D. Under normal conditions, the water customer will be notified of any anticipated interruptions of water service by the city. (Ord. 177 § 11, 1994) 13.04.140 - Prohibited acts. A. 1. No person shall connect to, tap on, or discharge water from any water line or water main belonging to the city without first obtaining the permission of the city to do so and paying the required deposits, tap fees and connection charges therefor. 2. No person shall break, alter, change the reading of, or tamper with the mechanism of any water meter within the city of Auburn without proper authority from the city. 3. No person shall attach any pipe, device or mechanism of any kind or type to any water line, pipe or main, in such a manner as to cause any water to flow through, by or around any city water meter without the meter properly measuring and recording the quantity of water used thereof. 4. No person shall attach any pipe, device or other mechanism of any type or kind to any city water line, pipe or main where a water meter has yet to be installed or where the water taken therefrom does not flow through a water meter without first obtaining permission from the city. 5. No person shall cover a water meter with dirt or other materials so that the cover or top of the water meter is not visible to officials, employees or agents of the city. 6. No person shall, without authority from the city, reconnect or turn on any water connection, where the same has been disconnected by city officials, employees or agents for nonpayment of water bill(s), or for other reasons. 7. No person shall take water from a fire hydrant located within the city without first obtaining permission from the water superintendent. Official use of water from hydrants is not covered by this prohibition. B. It shall be presumed that the principal occupant of the premises who is primarily liable for the payments of water bills, whether such person be an owner or a tenant, is the individual who violated any of the enumerated provisions in subsection A of this section when such occurs on his/her property or premises. C. It is unlawful for any person to interfere or intermeddle with any reservoir, water tank and/or tower, basin, pump, pump house, or the water therein, or the water mains, lines, pipes, hydrants, plugs, meters or any connection of the water system, or to climb tanks, towers or standpipes, or to throw anything in same or in a reservoir or in any part of the water system. (Ord. 177 § 12, 1994) 13.04.150 - Removal of meter and reinstallation charges. In the event of tampering or unlawful interference with a water meter, the city clerk is authorized to cause said water meter to be removed and water lines closed and, thereafter, said water meter shall not be reinstalled and water service reconnected until all past due bills have been paid and a reinstallation charge paid in the amount of one-half of the normal new meter installation charge. In the event that the water meter removed has been damaged or so tampered with as to render it ineffective without repair or reinstallation, then and in that event, the reinstallation charge shall be the rate it is now or hereafter established for the installation of a new meter. (Ord. 177 § 13, 1994) 13.04.160 - Right of entry. All officials, employees or authorized agents of the city of Auburn shall have the right, at all hours, to enter upon the property of any water customer for the purposes of inspecting pipes and fixtures, setting and repairing meters, turning water off or on, and to examine the sanitary conditions incident to the use of the water thereon. (Ord. 177 § 14, 1994) 13.04.170 - Drought-related shortages. The mayor and council of the city of Auburn reserve the right to place certain restrictions on the use of potable water during a time designated by proper authorities as a water emergency, and may discontinue all water services, if the situation so demands, for a period of time to be decided by the mayor and council at a regular or special meeting. The mayor and council may direct, at any regular or special meeting, that water customers of the city of Auburn comply with any and/or all restrictions presently in effect in the unincorporated areas of Barrow County, Georgia and/or Gwinnett County, Georgia. (Ord. 177 § 15, 1994) 13.04.180 - Backflow prevention. In order to prevent the possible contamination of the city of Auburn's water system because of backflow, the following procedures are adopted: A. All water and service lines located on each property served by a city of Auburn water meter will be checked to ensure compliance with the Federal Safe Drinking Water Act and the Georgia Rules for Safe Drinking Water which require suitable backflow prevention devices to be in place. B. Should it be determined that a water customer does not have such backflow prevention devices as are necessary, in the judgment of the city of Auburn, to prevent contamination of water should backflow occur, the water customer will be required to install such devices as may be deemed necessary. If the water customer fails or refuses to install such devices, the city is authorized, after notice to the water customer, to install said devices and bill to the water customer the reasonable expenses of installation. C. All future connections to the city of Auburn water system will be completed with the appropriate backflow prevention devices installed at the expense of the water customer, builder, contractor, etc. (Ord. 177 § 16, 1994) 13.04.190 - Installation of tracer. A. The following procedures are established to aid appropriate officials, employees and authorized agents of the city of Auburn in locating PVC or other nonmetallic water mains and service lines installed within the city of Auburn water service area: 1. A wire type tracing material will be installed with all PVC or other nonmetallic water mains and service lines installed within the city of Auburn water service area. 2. All curbs and gutters will be installed prior to the installation of water mains. 3. All water mains will be located four feet from back of curb at a depth of four feet to the top of the pipe. 4. Developers will install a two-inch conduit capped on both ends at all points requiring long side service. 5. Each conduit will have a tracer wire installed at the recommended depth. 6. The conduit shall extend past the back of the curb by two feet on each side. 7. The conduit is to be installed thirty inches below finished grade of the roadway and the curb is to be marked with paint with a "W" at each point that a conduit is laid. B. "As built" plans will be furnished to the city of Auburn showing the location of all service conduits as soon as possible after installation. Subdivision plats will not be considered final until these plans are available. C. Officials, employees or agents of the city of Auburn must be able to locate the conduit, as required heretofore, within two feet of either side of the marked area. If the conduit cannot be located within the permitted area, city employees will proceed to bore the road at the developer's or owner's expense at a rate of seven dollars and fifty cents per foot of bore. D. In the event that the developer fails to provide adequate markings or an "as built" plat showing the locations of the conduits, the city reserves the right to withhold all meter installations until that information is made available. (Ord. 177 § 17, 1994) 13.04.200 - Customers outside the city limits. Water customers located outside the corporate boundaries of the city of Auburn are subject to the rules and regulations contained in this chapter. Any extensions of water service outside the city limits of Auburn that are paid for by the water customer in lieu of any assessment for the connection of water service will become the property of the city of Auburn when such lines are connected to the city of Auburn's water system. (Ord. 177 § 18, 1994) 13.04.210 - New construction. All contractors or builders are responsible to see that all meters are easily accessible to officials, employees or agents of the city of Auburn, i.e., free of concrete, landscaping which would cover meters with grass, shrubs or trees, etc. Failure to comply with this requirement after receiving notification in writing will result in a charge to the contractor of seventy-five dollars to clear the meter area. Meters or meter boxes once set by the city in working order will be the builder's responsibility if broken either by landscaper, builder or others and the actual costs will be charged to the permitted builder for replacing the broken meter and/or meter box. (Ord. 177 § 19, 1994) 13.04.220 - Violation—Penalty. Any person violating any provision of this chapter may be deemed guilty of violating a city ordinance and may be punished by a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars. Each day that such a violation of this chapter is deemed to exist will constitute a separate offense under this chapter. (Ord. 177 § 20, 1994)

div.head: Chapter 13.08 - WATER SHORTAGE EMERGENCIES
div.p:
Sections:
13.08.010 - Declaration of water shortage. The mayor of the city of Auburn shall be empowered to declare a water shortage emergency and cause the provisions of this chapter to be effective. This chapter shall be in effect until the mayor declares an end to the water shortage. (Ord. 214 § 1, 1995) 13.08.020 - Prohibitions. A. During those times designated by the mayor as times of water shortage and emergency, no person who resides or business which is located within the city limits of Auburn or who purchases water from the city of Auburn shall use water to sprinkle a lawn, or use water through a hose to water any garden, tree, or shrub, except between the hours of nine a.m. and three p.m. or other such hours as the mayor may prescribe or deem necessary. These restrictions shall apply to all residences and to all businesses and institutions having lawns, gardens, trees or shrubs, and shall be followed at all parks and public buildings owned by the city. These restrictions shall not apply to any person, firm or corporation engaged in the business of growing or selling plants of any kind. B. During those times designated by the mayor as times of water shortage and emergency, no person who resides or business which is located within the city limits of Auburn or who purchases water from the city of Auburn shall use water from a hose to wash automobiles or other vehicles, except between the hours of nine a.m. and three p.m. or other such hours as the mayor may prescribe or deem necessary and except at places of business where automobiles and other vehicles are washed on every business day either with attendants, with automatic equipment or by self service. C. During those times designated by the mayor as times of water shortage and emergency, no person who resides or business which is located within the city limits of Auburn or who purchases water from the city of Auburn shall fill a swimming pool or add water to any swimming pool, except between the hours of nine a.m. and three p.m. or other such hours as the mayor may prescribe or deem necessary. D. During those times designated by the mayor as times of water shortage and emergency, no person who resides or business which is located within the city limits of Auburn or who purchases water from the city of Auburn shall use water from a hose to wash structures, objects or surfaces, except between the hours of nine a.m. and three p.m. or other such hours as the mayor may prescribe or deem necessary. This subsection shall not apply to any person, firm or corporation which operates a pressure washing business and whose employee upon demand by an agent of the city of Auburn can produce proof of payment of an occupation tax to the city of Auburn or other Georgia municipality or county. E. During those times designated by the mayor as times of water shortage and emergency, no person who resides or business which is located within the city limits of Auburn or who purchases water from the city of Auburn shall use water from a hose to clean any animal, except between the hours of nine a.m. and three p.m. or other such hours as the mayor may prescribe or deem necessary. This subsection shall not apply to veterinarians or places of business where animal husbandry is practiced. (Ord. 214 §§ 2—6, 1995) 13.08.030 - Determination of violation. No person shall be convicted of violating this chapter unless such person in fact turned on water, directed the turning on of water, or kept water turned on after learning it was turned on in violation of this chapter, or failed to turn off automatic devices capable of turning on water in violation of this chapter. It will not be necessary, however, to present a witness who saw the accused turning on the water, if the circumstances indicate the accused did turn on the water. (Ord. 214 § 7, 1995) 13.08.040 - Notification of regulations. The city water department shall from time to time send, along with the monthly water bill, an explanation of the regulations set out in this chapter. (Ord. 214 § 8, 1995) 13.08.050 - Violation—Penalty. A. Any person, firm or corporation convicted of violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined not less than fifty dollars nor more than five hundred dollars for each offense. In determining the amount of the fine, the judge shall consider whether the person cited has previously been convicted of violating this chapter. B. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues unless a citation is issued and an additional violation occurs the same day following the issuance of the citation, in which case each offense shall constitute a violation even if occurring on the same day. C. Upon a third conviction of this chapter per water customer within a three-month period, the water supply of the water customer may be terminated until such customer deposits with the city of Auburn a deposit of five hundred dollars, such deposit returnable at the conclusion of the declared water shortage emergency period unless forfeited upon a fourth conviction during the declared water shortage emergency. (Ord. 214 § 9, 1995) 13.08.060 - Authority to issue citations. The city of Auburn police department and water department shall have the authority to issue citations to persons suspected of violating this chapter, such citations to be brought before the municipal court of the city of Auburn. (Ord. 214 § 10, 1995) 13.08.070 - Exemptions. This chapter shall not apply to those residences and businesses which obtain one hundred percent of water used for any of the above water usage activities from private wells located on the subject property. (Ord. 214 § 11, 1995)

div.head: Chapter 13.15 - SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT FEES
div.p:
Sections:
13.15.020 - Fees. A. Billing. For all residences, the following rates shall apply effective with billings for solid waste that will be due on or after January 15, 2003: 1. The city shall charge the cost assessed by the service provider plus eight percent. The city clerk shall bill all residences of the city on the monthly water bill. 2. The city shall distribute the eight percent as follows: a. Seven percent to be dedicated to the roads project fund. b. One percent to be dedicated to reduce the administrative costs of the city for providing this service to its citizens. B. The city hereby amends its solid waste management plan to reflect this modification in its billing practices. (Ord. 270 § 1, 2002)

div.head: Chapter 13.20 - IDENTITY THEFT PREVENTION PROGRAM
div.p: 13.20.010 - Short title. This chapter shall be known as the "Identity Theft Prevention Program." (Ord. No. 09-010, § 1, 11-6-08) 13.20.020 - Purpose. The purpose of this chapter is to comply with 16 CFR § 681.2 in order to detect, prevent and mitigate identity theft by identifying and detecting identity theft red flags and by responding to such red flags in a manner that will prevent identity theft. (Ord. No. 09-010, § 1, 11-6-08) 13.20.030 - Definitions. For purposes of this chapter, the following definitions apply: A. "City" means the City of Auburn. B. "Covered account" means: 1. An account that a financial institution or creditor offers or maintains, primarily for personal, family, or household purposes, that involves or is designed to permit multiple payments or transactions, such as a credit card account, mortgage loan, automobile loan, margin account, cell phone account, utility account, checking account, or savings account; and 2. Any other account that the financial institution or creditor offers or maintains for which there is a reasonably foreseeable risk to customers or to the safety and soundness of the financial institution or creditor from identity theft, including financial, operational, compliance, reputation, or litigation risks. C. "Credit" means the right granted by a creditor to a debtor to defer payment of debt or to incur debts and defer its payment or to purchase property or services and defer payment therefore. D. "Creditor" means any person who regularly extends, renews, or continues credit; any person who regularly arranges for the extension, renewal, or continuation of credit; or any assignee of an original creditor who participates in the decision to extend, renew, or continue credit and includes utility companies and telecommunications companies. E. "Customer" means a person that has a covered account with a creditor. F. "Identity theft" means a fraud committed or attempted using identifying information of another person without authority. G. "Person" means a natural person, a corporation, government or governmental subdivision or agency, trust, estate, partnership, cooperative, or association. H. "Personal identifying information" means a person's credit card account information, debit card information bank account information and drivers' license information and for a natural person includes their Social Security Number, mother's birth name, and date of birth. I. "Red flag" means a pattern, practice, or specific activity that indicates the possible existence of identity theft. J. "Service provider" means a person that provides a service directly to the city. (Ord. No. 09-010, § 1, 11-6-08) 13.20.040 - Findings. 1. The city is a creditor pursuant to 16 CFR § 681.2 due to its provision or maintenance of covered accounts for which payment is made in arrears. 2. Covered accounts offered to customers for the provision of city services include water and garbage. 3. The city's previous experience with identity theft related to covered accounts is as follows: No previous experience related to identity theft. 4. The processes of opening a new covered account, restoring an existing covered account, making payments on such accounts, and inquiries made to such accounts have been identified as potential processes in which identity theft could occur. 5. The city limits access to personal identifying information to those employees responsible for or otherwise involved in opening or restoring covered accounts or accepting payment for use of covered accounts. Information provided to such employees is entered directly into the city's computer system and is not otherwise recorded. 6. The city determines that there is a Medium risk of identity theft occurring in the following ways (if any): a. Use by an applicant of another person's personal identifying information to establish a new covered account; b. Use of a previous customer's personal identifying information by another person in an effort to have service restored in the previous customer's name; c. Use of another person's credit card, bank account, or other method of payment by a customer to pay such customer's covered account or accounts; d. Use by a customer desiring to restore such customer's covered account of another person's credit card, bank account, or other method of payment. (Ord. No. 09-010, § 1, 11-6-08) 13.20.050 - Process of establishing a covered account. 1. As a precondition to opening a covered account in the city, each applicant shall provide the city with personal identifying information of the customer: a valid U.S. issued identification card, or driver's license, containing a photograph of the customer or a valid passport, for customers who are not natural persons then a resident alien card or work visa, and all customers must provide their Social Security Number and/or tax ID number. Such information shall be entered from an application form directly into the city's computer system and said application form will be filed within city hall. 2. Each account shall be assigned an account number which shall be unique to that account. The city may utilize computer software to encrypt account numbers. (Ord. No. 09-010, § 1, 11-6-08) 13.20.060 - Access to covered account information. 1. Access to customer accounts shall be password protected and shall be limited to authorized city personnel. 2. Such password(s) shall be changed by the director of the department providing the service for which the covered account is created on a regular basis, shall be at least eight characters in length and shall contain letters, numbers and symbols. 3. Any unauthorized access to or other breach of customer accounts is to be reported immediately to the city administrator and the password changed immediately. 4. Personal identifying information included in customer accounts is considered confidential and any request or demand for such information shall be immediately forwarded to the city administrator and the city attorney. (Ord. No. 09-010, § 1, 11-6-08) 13.20.070 - Credit card payments. 1. In the event that credit card payments that are made over the Internet are processed through a third-party service provider, such third-party service provider shall certify that it has an adequate identity theft prevention program in place that is applicable to such payments. 2. All credit card payments made over the telephone or the city's website shall be entered directly into the customer's account information in the computer data base. 3. Account statements and receipts for covered accounts shall include only the last four digits of the credit or debit card or the bank account used for payment of the covered account. (Ord. No. 09-010, § 1, 11-6-08) 13.20.080 - Sources and types of red flags. All employees responsible for or involved in the process of opening a covered account, restoring a covered account or accepting payment for a covered account shall check for red flags as indicators of possible identity theft and such red flags may include: 1. Alerts from consumer reporting agencies, fraud detection agencies or service providers. Examples of alerts include but are not limited to: a. A fraud or active duty alert that is included with a consumer report; b. A notice of credit freeze in response to a request for a consumer report; c. A notice of address discrepancy provided by a consumer reporting agency; d. Indications of a pattern of activity in a consumer report that is inconsistent with the history and usual pattern of activity of an applicant or customer, such as: i. A recent and significant increase in the volume of inquiries; ii. An unusual number of recently established credit relationships; iii. A material change in the use of credit, especially with respect to recently established credit relationships; or iv. An account that was closed for cause or identified for abuse of account privileges by a financial institution or creditor. 2. Suspicious documents. Examples of suspicious documents include: a. Documents provided for identification that appear to be altered or forged; b. Identification on which the photograph or physical description is inconsistent with the appearance of the applicant or customer; c. Identification on which the information is inconsistent with information provided by the applicant or customer; d. Identification on which the information is inconsistent with readily accessible information that is on file with the financial institution or creditor, such as a signature card or a recent check; or e. An application that appears to have been altered or forged, or appears to have been destroyed and reassembled. 3. Suspicious personal identification, such as suspicious address change. Examples of suspicious identifying information include: a. Personal identifying information that is inconsistent with external information sources used by the financial institution or creditor. For example: i. The address does not match any address in the consumer report; or ii. The Social Security Number (SSN) has not been issued, or is listed on the Social Security Administration's Death Master File. b. Personal identifying information provided by the customer is not consistent with other personal identifying information provided by the customer, such as a lack of correlation between the SSN range and date of birth. c. Personal identifying information or a phone number or address, is associated with known fraudulent applications or activities as indicated by internal or third-party sources used by the financial institution or creditor. d. Other information provided, such as fictitious mailing address, mail drop addresses, jail addresses, invalid phone numbers, pager numbers or answering services, is associated with fraudulent activity. e. The SSN provided is the same as that submitted by other applicants or customers. f. The address or telephone number provided is the same as or similar to the account number or telephone number submitted by an unusually large number of applicants or customers. g. The applicant or customer fails to provide all required personal identifying information on an application or in response to notification that the application is incomplete. h. Personal identifying information is not consistent with personal identifying information that is on file with the city. i. The applicant or customer cannot provide authenticating information beyond that which generally would be available from a wallet or consumer report. 4. Unusual use of or suspicious activity relating to a covered account. Examples of suspicious activity include: a. Shortly following the notice of a change of address for an account, city receives a request for the addition of authorized users on the account. b. A new revolving credit account is used in a manner commonly associated with known patterns of fraud patterns. For example: i. The customer fails to make the first payment or makes an initial payment but no subsequent payments. c. An account is used in a manner that is not consistent with established patterns of activity on the account. There is, for example: i. Nonpayment when there is no history of late or missed payments; ii. A material change in purchasing or spending patterns; d. An account that has been inactive for a long period of time is used (taking into consideration the type of account, the expected pattern of usage and other relevant factors). e. Mail sent to the customer is returned repeatedly as undeliverable although transactions continue to be conducted in connection with the customer's account. f. The city is notified that the customer is not receiving paper account statements. g. The city is notified of unauthorized charges or transactions in connection with a customer's account. h. The city is notified by a customer, law enforcement or another person that it has opened a fraudulent account for a person engaged in identity theft. 5. Notice from customers, law enforcement, victims or other reliable sources regarding possible identity theft or phishing relating to covered accounts. (Ord. No. 09-010, § 1, 11-6-08) 13.20.090 - Prevention and mitigation of identity theft. 1. In the event that any city employee responsible for or involved in restoring an existing covered account or accepting payment for a covered account becomes aware of red flags indicating possible identity theft with respect to existing covered accounts, such employee shall use his or her discretion to determine whether such red flag or combination of red flags suggests a threat of identity theft. If, in his or her discretion, such employee determines that identity theft or attempted identity theft is likely or probable, such employee shall immediately report such red flags to their department head. If, in his or her discretion, such employee deems that identity theft is unlikely or that reliable information is available to reconcile red flags, the employee shall convey this information to their department head, who may in his or her discretion determine that no further action is necessary. If the department head in his or her discretion determines that further action is necessary, a city employee shall perform one or more of the following responses, as determined to be appropriate by the city administrator: a. Contact the customer; b. Make the following changes to the account if, after contacting the customer, it is apparent that someone other than the customer has accessed the customer's covered account: i. Change any account numbers, passwords, security codes, or other security devices that permit access to an account; or ii. Close the account; c. Cease attempts to collect additional charges from the customer and decline to sell the customer's account to a debt collector in the event that the customer's account has been accessed without authorization and such access has caused additional charges to accrue; d. Notify a debt collector within twenty-four hours of the discovery of likely or probable identity theft relating to a customer account that has been sold to such debt collector in the event that a customer's account has been sold to a debt collector prior to the discovery of the likelihood or probability of identity theft relating to such account; e. Notify law enforcement, in the event that someone other than the customer has accessed the customer's account causing additional charges to accrue or accessing personal identifying information; or f. Take other appropriate action to prevent or mitigate identity theft. 2. In the event that any city employee responsible for or involved in opening a new covered account becomes aware of red flags indicating possible identity theft with respect an application for a new account, such employee shall use his or her discretion to determine whether such red flag or combination of red flags suggests a threat of identity theft. If, in his or her discretion, such employee determines that identity theft or attempted identity theft is likely or probable, such employee shall immediately report such red flags to their department head. If, in his or her discretion, such employee deems that identity theft is unlikely or that reliable information is available to reconcile red flags, the employee shall convey this information to their department head, who may in his or her discretion determine that no further action is necessary. If the department head in his or her discretion determines that further action is necessary, a city employee shall perform one or more of the following responses, as determined to be appropriate by the city administrator: a. Request additional identifying information from the applicant; b. Deny the application for the new account; c. Notify law enforcement of possible identity theft; or d. Take other appropriate action to prevent or mitigate identity theft. (Ord. No. 09-010, § 1, 11-6-08) 13.20.100 - Updating the program. The city council shall annually review and, as deemed necessary by the council, update the Identity Theft Prevention Program along with any relevant red flags in order to reflect changes in risks to customers or to the safety and soundness of the city and its covered accounts from identity theft. In so doing, the city council shall consider the following factors and exercise its discretion in amending the program: 1. The city's experiences with identity theft; 2. Updates in methods of identity theft; 3. Updates in customary methods used to detect, prevent, and mitigate identity theft; 4. Updates in the types of accounts that the city offers or maintains; and 5. Updates in service provider arrangements. (Ord. No. 09-010, § 1, 11-6-08) 13.20.110 - Program administration. Department heads are responsible for oversight of the program and for program implementation. The city administrator is responsible for reviewing reports prepared by staff regarding compliance with red flag requirements and with recommending material changes to the program, as necessary in the opinion of the city administrator, to address changing identity theft risks and to identify new or discontinued types of covered accounts. Any recommended material changes to the program shall be submitted to the city council for consideration by the council. 1. The department heads will report to the city administrator at least annually, on compliance with the red flag requirements. The report will address material matters related to the program and evaluate issues such as: a. The effectiveness of the policies and procedures of city in addressing the risk of identity theft in connection with the opening of covered accounts and with respect to existing covered accounts; b. Service provider arrangements; c. Significant incidents involving identity theft and management's response; and d. Recommendations for material changes to the program. 2. The department heads are responsible for providing training to all employees responsible for or involved in opening a new covered account, restoring an existing covered account or accepting payment for a covered account with respect to the implementation and requirements of the identity theft prevention program. The department heads shall exercise his or her discretion in determining the amount and substance of training necessary. (Ord. No. 09-010, § 1, 11-6-08) 13.20.120 - Outside service providers. In the event that the city engages a service provider to perform an activity in connection with one or more covered accounts the department head shall exercise his or her discretion in reviewing such arrangements in order to ensure, to the best of his or her ability, that the service provider's activities are conducted in accordance with policies and procedures, agreed upon by contract, that are designed to detect any red flags that may arise in the performance of the service provider's activities and take appropriate steps to prevent or mitigate identity theft. (Ord. No. 09-010, § 1, 11-6-08)

div.head: Chapter 13.30 - TREATMENT OF ADDRESS DISCREPANCIES
div.p: 13.30.010 - Short title. [This chapter shall be known as the] "Treatment of Address Discrepancies." (Ord. No. 09-010, § 2, 11-6-08) 13.30.020 - Purpose. Pursuant to 16 CFR § 681.1, the purpose of this chapter is to establish a process by which the city will be able to form a reasonable belief that a consumer report relates to the consumer about whom it has requested a consumer credit report when the city has received a notice of address discrepancy. (Ord. No. 09-010, § 2, 11-6-08) 13.30.030 - Definitions. For purposes of this chapter, the following definitions apply: 1. "Notice of address discrepancy" means a notice sent to a user by a consumer reporting agency pursuant to 15 U.S.C. § 1681(c)(h)(1), that informs the user of a substantial difference between the address for the consumer that the user provided to request the consumer report and the address(es) in the agency's file for the consumer. 2. "City" means City of Auburn. (Ord. No. 09-010, § 2, 11-6-08) 13.30.040 - Policy. In the event that the city receives a notice of address discrepancy, the city employee responsible for verifying consumer addresses for the purpose of providing the municipal service or account sought by the consumer shall perform one or more of the following activities, as determined to be appropriate by such employee: 1. Compare the information in the consumer report with: a. Information the city obtains and uses to verify a consumer's identity in accordance with the requirements of the Customer Information Program rules implementing 31 U.S.C. § 5318(1); b. Information the city maintains in its own records, such as applications for service, change of address notices, other customer account records or tax records; or c. Information the city obtains from third-party sources that are deemed reliable by the relevant city employee; or 2. Verify the information in the consumer report with the consumer. (Ord. No. 09-010, § 2, 11-6-08) 13.30.050 - Furnishing consumer's address to consumer reporting agency. 1. In the event that the city reasonably confirms that an address provided by a consumer to the city is accurate, the city is required to provide such address to the consumer reporting agency from which the city received a notice of address discrepancy with respect to such consumer. This information is required to be provided to the consumer reporting agency when: a. The city is able to form a reasonable belief that the consumer report relates to the consumer about whom the city requested the report; b. The city establishes a continuing relation with the consumer; and c. The city regularly and in the ordinary course of business provides information to the consumer reporting agency from which it received the notice of address discrepancy. 2. Such information shall be provided to the consumer reporting agency as part of the information regularly provided by the city to such agency for the reporting period in which the city establishes a relationship with the customer. (Ord. No. 09-010, § 2, 11-6-08) 13.30.060 - Methods of confirming consumer addresses. The city employee charged with confirming consumer addresses may, in his or her discretion, confirm the accuracy of an address through one or more of the following methods: 1. Verifying the address with the consumer; 2. Reviewing the city's records to verify the consumer's address; 3. Verifying the address through third-party sources; or 4. Using other reasonable processes. (Ord. No. 09-010, § 2, 11-6-08)

div.head: Chapter 13.34 - WATER SYSTEM BACKFLOW PREVENTION
div.p: 13.34.010 - Connection control and backflow prevention. 1. Purpose: The purpose of this chapter is: a. To protect the public potable water supply of the city of Auburn from the possibility of contamination or pollution by isolating within the consumer's internal distribution system(s) or the consumer's private water system(s) such contaminants or pollutants which could backflow into the public water systems; and, b. To promote the elimination or control of existing cross connections, actual or potential, between the consumer's in-plant potable water system(s) and non-potable water system(s), plumbing fixtures and industrial piping systems; and, c. To provide for the maintenance of a continuing program of cross connection control that will systematically and effectively prevent the contamination or pollution of all potable water systems. 2. Responsibility: The Georgia Rules for Safe Drinking Water (391-3-5.-13.2) require that a supplier of water or any person having possession or control of facilities, which may cause that contamination of a public water system, has the responsibility to prevent water from unapproved sources or any contaminants from entering the public water system. The director of utilities shall be responsible for the protection of the public potable water distribution system from contamination or pollution due to the backflow of contaminants or pollutants through the water service connection. If, in the judgment of said director of utilities, an approved backflow prevention assembly is required at the consumer's water service connection; or, within the consumer's private water system for the safety of the water system, the director of utilities or his designated agent shall give notice in writing to said consumer to install such an approved backflow prevention assembly(s) at a specific location(s) on his premises.
